editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Man's the Maſter: A COMEDY.
WRITTEN BY Sir WILLIAM D'AVENANT, KNIGHT.
Printed for Henry Herringman, at the Blew-Anchor, in the Lower-Walk of the New-Exchange. 1669.

lg.l: NO Country Lady ever yet did ask
Such ſhrewd advice before a Ball or Maſque
(When curious dreſſing is the Courts great task)
As now young Poets doe, in this nice Age,
To gain the froward Lovers of the Stage;
Whoſe heat of humors nothing can aſſwage.
The Muſe, diſdain'd, does as fond Women doe;
Inſtead of being courted ſhe courts you:
But Women are leſs valu'd when they wooe.
And as young Poets, like young Ladies, fear
A Concourſe, great as this Aſſembly here,
Till they ſeek councell how they ſhould appear,
So all old Poets, like old Ladies, may
Be more afraid to venture the ſurvay
Of many apt to cenſure their decay.
Both know they have been out of faſhion long;
And, e'r they come before a ſhining Throng,
Would dreſs themſelves by Patterns of the Young.
Well, our old Poet hopes this Comedie
Will ſomewhat in the fine new faſhion be;
But, if all gay, 'twould not with Age agree.
A little he was fain to moralize
That he might ſerve your Minds as well as Eyes:
The Proverb ſayes, Be merry and be wiſe.
This, Gentlemen, is all he bad me ſay
Of his important Trifle call'd a Play;
For which, he does confeſs, you dearly pay.
But he did fear that he could hardly make
A Prologue ſo in faſhion as might take,
For he does much of too much boldneſs lack.
He never durſt, nor ever thought it fit,
To cenſure thoſe who Judges are of Wit.
Now you expect the Rime will end in Pit.

p.hi: The Scene MADRID. And in one Houſe.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Lucilla, and Laura with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: YOu have ſerv'd me but two days, and are you weary already?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray add the nights to the days; for I have not ſlept ſince I came into your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Love has ordain'd us for theſe Journeys; and will, I hope, bring us at laſt where we may reſt quietly.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, to the laſt Inn of all Travailers, where we ſhall meet Worms inſtead of Fleas; Lovers never reſt quietly till they lodge at the ſign of the Grave.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: P • ithee be patient Laura.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If I had been waiting-woman to Will of the Wisp, I could not have wander'd with ſo much uncertainty as when I follow a Miſtreſs led about by Love.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But, Laura, I follow you now.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You may with eaſe enough when I'm ſo tir'd that I can go no farther; this is the pretty Foot belonging to a Leg; which (though I ſay't) was fit to lead a Dance in Hymens Hall.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: And does it limp now, and grow weary of the errands of two days.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You have little reaſon to blame that Leg which has been ſo nimble in your ſervice; but the other will follow it no further. Me thinks it has got a ſhackle inſtead of a Garter She limps a little.

div.stage: Enter Sancho with a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Take heed, Laura; I ſee light.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, what would you ſee, darkneſs? are not your eyes made for the light?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: 'Tis a Man; He ſeems to ſeek ſome body with a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: He ſeeks me here by appointment.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I'l retire to this Portico.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Doe, whilſt I accoſt him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis Sancho, Don Ferdinando's Steward; he was my ſworn Brother over a Poſſit, he is by the length of his Beard and the heat of his Conſtitution, a very Goat.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You need not fear his loſs of time; I uſe to call him my Brother-Brevity; He is ſo thrifty of his ſpeech, that his Tongue does ſeldom allow his thoughts above two words to expreſs them.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Are not you my Brother Sancho?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Have you contriv'd a way to conceal my Lady in your Maſters houſe?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Can you admit her now?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: May it be to morrow?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: It may.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I'l attend you in the morning.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Doe.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Pray name the hour.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Nine.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: My Miſtriſs is very ſenſible of your care, and would know if I may have leave to give you this Gold?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I hope you hate not me, nor the preſent.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Are we both acceptable?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Both. — He looks on the Gold.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis very Gold; and Signior Sancho you ſhall find me to be as true metal as it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'l try. — Offers to kiſs her.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Not ſo ſoon, good Signior Sancho, Bring me to the Wedding night, and then try if, like Gold, I can endure the touch.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Humph! —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Lovers may pretend to have true Metal, but Mariage is the Touch-ſtone.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Of Fools. aſide.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Hands off, good Signior Sancho. You want ſleep, Good night, Pray let me go. —

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Paſſe. — Exit Sancho.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, Madam, we may haſten home, Nine is the appointed hour when you ſhall have admittance.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: After I have ſought opportunity, I am afraid to find it.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Madam, I do not yet underſtand your intrigues of Love. You are afraid to find the opportunity you ſeek, and I, poor wretch, ſeek more opportunities than I fear I ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Lord help thee,! thou doſt want a great deal of ſorrow to make thee a little wiſe. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, by your favour, you are either mad, or the Devil is malicious to bring you to Madrid, at ſo unſeaſonable an hour, after riding poſt, or rather flying, without meat or drink, as empty as wild Hawks, and as uncertain of your Quarry.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I confeſs thou maiſt be tir'd all over, all but thy Tongue, and that can never be weary. The Street where we are now, is that which I have ſought.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: What will you do here, go ſee Don Ferdinand when 'tis paſt Midnight?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Yes, and this very night I'l viſit Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: 'Tis ill to have an empty ſtomach, but worſe to have an empty head.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Todelet, I know you are hungry, but hunger makes you fitter for watching, I'l not ſtirr out of this ſtreet till I ſee my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Remember 'tis paſt One, a ſeaſon when Don Ferdinand's Gates are always ſhut: we have ridden this morning from Burgos. I know no kind of Lovers but Owls would have choſen the night for a journey.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: To love nothing but ſleep and eating is to be a Beaſt in the habit of a Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: How I hate raillery?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: And I eating and ſleep, in compariſon of this Picture of Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You are one of thoſe who are fill'd with wild-fire at ſight of a cold Picture; and if Maſter Painter, has luckily drawn a Snout of Ivory and a Mouth of Coral, which perhaps does incloſe an ill Tongue and worſe Teeth, then he makes you mad of a Miſtreſs; Will a Picture reveal whether her crooked body be arm'd with a Coat of Mail, or whether ſhe be ſome Skeleton whoſe Beauties lie at night upon her dreſſing-cloth? you'l not be much pity'd if men find you ill provided of a Woman, ſince you'l be gull'd with one before you have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Thou art as froward at this time o'th night as a wak'd Child.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Wou'd any Man keep patience about him when he muſt run in the dark from Street to Street, and grope out his way like a blind Man without a Dog? or ſtand ſo long under a Balcone (lifting himſelf upon one leg to ſtare higher about him) till he ſhift his feet as often as a Stork?

sp.speaker: Don John.
sp.p: My Picture was rarely drawn: and ſure it could not chuſe but pleaſe my Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I know the contrary.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: What ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I tell you it has rather diſpleas'd her.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: How the Devil canſt thou know that!

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Alas, I know it too well.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Hah! tell me how?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Good Sir, have patience! inſtead of your Picture ſhe received mine.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Traitor, 'tis well thou doſt not uſe to ſpeak truth, for elſe I ſhould ſearch for thy life in the very bottom of thy Bowels.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You may, Sir, and begin as my Throat: But in piercing my body, I pray ſpare my Doublet for I made it new at Burgos.

sp.speaker: D. Joh.
sp.p: Pox of your Railery, Tell me what thou haſt done?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, put your anger up firſt.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I never had ſo much cauſe to let it out, But ſpeak, and let not Fear fright Truth from thee.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, when we left Flanders —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Well proceed.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You having your Brother ki • l'd, and a Siſter carried away by ſtealth (not knowing where, nor how, nor wherefore, nor by whom) you rode ſo faſt that you left all your judgement a great way behind you.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: To what purpoſe, Villain, doſt thou open theſe two wounds? proceed apace to thy Picture.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, I go as faſt as I can; but your anger interrupts me ſo, that I'm fain ſometimes to go back to recover my Tongue, though I have nothing within me but what is much to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Why doſt thou not render it in few words?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I cannot, Sir, for I always ſpeak things in order, but for your Picture which I had e'n forgot —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Was ever Man ſo tir'd with the tedious length of nothing?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: We were but newly return'd to Caſtille when Don Ferdinand de Rochas propos'd his Daughter to you in Marriage: her Picture was made a Preſent to you, and the offer of Twenty thouſand Crowns in portion, and then you (t'inchant her with your own Picture as much as you were charm'd by hers) made haſte to ſend her it: and ſo, as the Proverb ſays, put an old Cat to an old Rat. It was a Lovers ſtratagem, and villanouſly ſubtle. But Heav'n (not always a Friend to Lovers) ordain'd a ſucceſs in ſpite of expectation.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Art thou about the Hiſtory of the World; and wilt thou not finiſh it till the World ends?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but I muſt refreſh my memory, for it is almoſt weary.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I would thy Tongue were ſo too.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p:
You remember that your Painter (in thankfulneſs for the great
reward you gave him) wou'd after he had drawn your Picture, take a little pains about mine.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I know that: but proceed.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Then you likewiſe know it coſt me nothing, Well, that Flemming's a brave man. None of your Jan Van Lievens, nor your Elſhamers, nor your Brauwers, nor your Joes Van Winghens ever drew like him. Then give him but a Rummer, over a Pickell'd Herring, and he will drink ſo kindly, as if he had the Heart of a Whale.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Wilt thou never conclude? haſt thou ſold, burnt, eat, or drank my Picture? Have I it yet, or was it ſent to Iſabella? ſpeak and be quick!

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: If you have not patience to ſtay awhile rather than hear ill news, but will needs ride Poſt to overtake the Devil, I will leave Flanders and goe the neareſt way to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Still wilt thou be tedious?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, ſince you love unwelcome brevity, know when I was to ſend away the laſt Packet, I would (being a little curious) compare the workmanſhip of my Picture with yours. I ſet them oppoſite to one another, turning my Eies often from this to that, and being call'd for in haſte by the Poſt-Boy, I put my little Picture in the Packet inſtead of yours!

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: How? yours inſtead of mine?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, your Picture had the happy lazineſs to ſtay here; but mine was deſtin'd to ride Poſt with the Devil to your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Canſt thou live, or I either, after I have heard this?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Good Sir, make uſe of patience as I did. Time, which wears out ſorrows as well as joys, has ſince th' unhappy accident given me a few quiet nights, and I have ceas'd to grieve for fear of being ſick.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Dog! what will ſhe ſay of thy horn-face, and of thy Badgers Noſe?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, ſhe will not think you very handſome, I mean in my Picture; but if we were both our own Painters we ſhould not want Beauty.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Peace, there comes one who perhaps knows Don Ferdinand's houſe, Goe, ask him.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: But Sir —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Well, ſpeak low.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Perhaps he • l expect a reward if he tells us. In Madrid you muſt hold out your Money if you do but ask what's a clock?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Unlucky Rogue, wou'd he would cudgel thee.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: He has not leiſure to do it; he ſeems in haſte.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Not to diſpleaſe you, Sir, where dwells Don Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: This is his houſe.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Are we in the right already? for this bout my Maſter has reaſon, the Father-in-law is found; and the Son-in-law-elect has nothing to do but to knock.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I begin to find my ſelf a Fool for having ſhew'd them where my Maſter is ſecretly enter'd, and whence I expect he'l preſently come forth; I muſt find ſome expedient.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Does he dwell here?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Yes, but he is ſick, and does not love noiſe, what are you?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: We, Sir, are Night-walkers; or rather men of Norway, a Norhern-Countrey where he is curs'd, who does not ſleep continually, for my part I never ſleep; and that's my Maſter, Sir, the greateſt waker in the World.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Or rather the greateſt Robber. He ſhall give me ſatisfaction for what he lately took from me; I know him well enough, and you were with him.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You are very chollerick, and I think ſomewhat mad. If I were ſo too, you would have little ſafety but in flying. Sir, as ſober as I am, I can ſcarce keep my hand from my hilt.

sp.speaker: To D. John.
sp.p: Sir! Sir! advance a little, I begin to grow ſoft, and were it not dark, I ſhould appear ſomewhat pale too.

sp.speaker: D. John to Steph.
sp.p: Approach Sir, come on towards me. I'l make you civil.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: How! Don of the dark? are you ſo brisk? but I ſhall take the pains to drive you a mile hence: for though you are Two (wou'd I were rid of 'em) if you dare follow me as faſt as I'l lead the way, ye ſhall come to a better place for fighting.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? I'l follow you, ſtay! I hear a noiſe. It ſeems to be above us.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p:
Pox on this chollerick Curr! if his barking had not frighted
me, I had, perhaps, without any danger, broke his very bones: but whence the Devil comes that other Devil? Don Lewis deſcends from the Balcone.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: They are going.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sure that's his Man whom he calls: he who gets way before us.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Either I am much couſen'd, or I am watch'd. But the noiſe of a quarrel will fright Iſabella. In care of her I muſt neglect my honour. Let's ſteal away, ſince it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: D. John to Tod.
sp.p: Stay, or thou art dead. Stay but one thruſt.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Maſter has mettal, but I'm no Touch-ſtone to try it on.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Give me thy name, or I'll take thy life.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I am Don Todelet of Segovia.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Three curſes on thee, and a thouſand on him that leapt from the Balcone. What's become of him.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: He flew through the dark like Lightning, and I like a furious Fool, follow'd him like Thunder, till the inviſible Rogue threaded a Lane as narrow as a Needles Eye. Well, I'm the Hercules whom you alwayes expoſe againſt Two. You are a little prompt, but, by your leave, Maſter; is it the Cuſtome of Madrid to ſcape thus out of a Windore?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Did'ſt thou perfectly diſcern him?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: And I, if it were poſſible, am quite confounded.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I muſt not here take up a quarrel at the firſt bound.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Methinks your mind is a little troubled.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: It is; and I have much cauſe, but let's conſult upon't.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's well ſaid; I never found my ſelf ſo much inclin'd to reaſoning, and, if you pleaſe, let's conſult ſoundly.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I was born at Burgos; left poor, but of a long race exempted even as far as my ſelf, from all diſgraces.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
At my return from the Warr to Burgos, I found my ſelf attacqu'd with two different Evils. I had a Brother murder'd and was
rob'd of a Siſter; though ſhe was bred with all the cares of honour. And this makes me exceeding chollerick.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's ill, very ill, exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: D. Ferdinand choſe me for a Husband to Iſabella; and ſhe has receiv'd thy Picture inſtead of mine.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's not very ill.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: We treated of this buſ • neſs in ſecret; and I took horſe for Madrid, where I now arrive late at night.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's a little ill.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Without ſeeking out a Lodging my love leads me directly hither.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's a little too ſoon.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I met before Don Ferdinands Houſe a Serving-man who thruſts me, by deſign, upon an Almain-quarrel.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's very true, but ſomewhat unwillingly, like a Coward as he is.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Perhaps 'twas for fear of ſcandal; for he did not approach us like a Coward.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: How did the unlucky Thief come then?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: He came on like the Lover of Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's very ill.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: 'Tis that which will wound my head more than his ſword.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Let's fall to reaſoning agen.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Ah! no more reaſoning, when reaſon grows ſuperfluous. But prithee mark the counſel which Love ſuggeſts to me. My hope lies in thee. To morrow, my dear Todelet, thou muſt paſs for my Maſter, and I for the Man. Thy Picture is to work Miracles. What ayl'ſt thou? doſt thou ſhake thy ears?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Theſe kind of diſguiſes ſmell too much of the Cudgel. I'ld rather proceed to reaſoning agen. For what will the world ſay? Don John is grown the Man, and Todelet the Maſter, and by ill fortune too; for perhaps, at laſt, your Miſtreſs may love me, and I her.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Fear not that; for then the miſchief will be mine: but I, being Tod'let, may get acquainted with my Rivals man. I'll be a Lover from the Kitchin to the Garret; and my Preſents ſhall open the Locks of every boſome: whilſt thou (eating like a Shanker, and
drinking like a Hole) ſhalt ſhine in gold Chains like the King of Peru, without having any ſhare of my ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I begin to like the Invention.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt be feaſted and cramm'd at Don Ferdinands; whilſt I am choak'd with my jealouſies.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: But may I not (to repreſent Don John the better) give your ſhoulders now and then a taſt of the Cudgel?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Yes, when we are alone, without Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l: Well, Vermechulli ſhall my Pallat pleaſe,
Serv'd in with Biſques, Ragous, and Intermets.
Wait cloſe upon Don Todelet, thy Maſter;
And thou mayſt be my Carver, or my Taſter.
If thou doſt fetch me Girls, and watch, and trudge well,
Thou ſhalt have food, if not, thou ſhalt have Cudgell.

div.head: ACT. II.

sp.speaker: Iſabel.
sp.p: BEttris, make up your Packet, without thinking to reconcile me by long rattle; I'll have no more of you.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Truly, Miſtreſs, I'm ignorant of the cauſe of your anger.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You know it not?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: If I do, may I never be haunted agen by men of Honour.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I diſmiſs you.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Well my conſcience is clear. If I have ever fail'd to ſerve you may I burſt like a boy'ld Pudding for want of pricking. But let Flatterers goe fine while Truth muſt be ſhut out o'dores and walk naked.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes, Dame Betteris, you are innocent: You have not open'd my Balcone to night, nor have walkt bare-footed to make leſs noiſe?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Alas! is that it? I left your lac'd linnen drying on a Line, and went into the Garden for fear ſome body ſhould ſteal it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes, and you diſcourſt with my Linnen: My ears deceiv'd me, I did not hear you talk.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Perhaps I was at prayers.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What, ſo loud?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Yes, that heav'n might hear me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And 'twas no man, but my linnen, that leapt down from my Balcone.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Pray do not believe it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I ſaw it, Bettris.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Miſtreſs, it is true. But Don Lewis —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: O Heav'n! how that name hurts me? was it Don Lewis?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, your fair Couſen.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My fair Couſen! Thou black wretch! for what deſign had he admittance?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: If 'tis a great ſin to be charitable you have cauſe to be angry. But if you will but hear me ſpeak —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You may ſpeak long enough before I believe you.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: 'Twas laſt night when that delicate Don Lewis came to ſee you, and becauſe it rain'd I let him into the Hall; and, much againſt my will; for I am tender of ſcandal: but the poor man, being impatient, went up; and preſently after I heard your Father Don Ferdinand ſpit aloud (for he alwayes coughs when he ſpits) and will be heard farr enough. I'll warrant him as ſound as any man of Madrid.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well, proceed to the ill purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: At this noiſe Don Lewis ſav'd himſelf in your Balcone, which he found half open, and I lockt him in till you arriv'd with the old man; with whom you diſcourſt too long, and made Don Lewis impatient agen.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Troth we were very uncivil to him.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I ſtay'd till you were a bed; and then (being in my nature alwayes inclin'd to charitable deeds) I went to free him from his impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Good heart!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He ſaid he muſt needs ſpeak with you one moment, but I warrant you, I was ſharp enough; and told him plainly that your Curtains were drawn.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: That was ſevere indeed.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
I ſaw tears fall from his eyes, and at the ſame time felt a few
Piſtols drop into my hand. He conjur'd me with ſuch ſweet words; calling me, my Heart, my dear Bettris, and then put on my finger a Diamond-Ring; which did ſo vex me that I was ready to fly in's face.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: That had been too cruel.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Nay, 〈◊〉 but that his ſuff • rings wrought me agen into pitty; for truly I cannot hate the man. But in your int'reſt I know no body.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I thank you, good Miſtreſs Bettris.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: But when he ſaw I was ſo much in earneſt that my face was all fire —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: He ſaw the fluſhing of your anger though it were dark; but indeed all kind of fire is moſt viſible at night.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He leapt from the Balcone into the Street; where I heard them cry, kill! kill! and this is the notable cauſe of your putting me away.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Well, you'll forgive me if I muſt needs be too blame.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I built my happineſs upon your Marriage. But if my zeal to ſerve you were known to Don John (who they ſay is come to Town) I ſhould hope for as ill ſucceſs as I have now.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How? Don John, too? the man I fear and moſt abhorre. After my rage againſt Don Lewis do you think to aſſwage me with the mention of Don John? Fare you well, Maid of Honour, let me ſee you no more.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let the Devill take Don Lewis who is the cauſe of this.

div.stage: Enter D. Ferdinand at the other Do • e.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What's the matter Bettris, are you weeping?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Sir, has diſmiſt me from her ſervice, and for nothing, Sir, but for wiſhing her favorable opinion of Don John, becauſe he deſerves it, and you deſire it.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p:
That's a ſmall cauſe for your diſmiſſion; but I'll endevor to reconcile you. Bid your Miſtreſs come hither. Exit Bettris. They have often little quarrels; ſometimes for a Curle diſorder'd, or a black-Patch miſ-plac'd; and more often they differ in expounding of Dreams: but this is no time for expulſion of ſervants. If Don John D' Alverad come, (who is expected to night) I'll throw away
my Staff, which is my Third Leg, and with my other Two lead 'em a Dance.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, you are perhaps, contriving my Marriage with Don John; but I hope you'll ordain me a death leſs cruel.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Minion, you are for ſome unexperienc'd Gallant, that never travail'd but Northward, and that was to obſerve the variety of Flaxen Hair, and to bring home Perewigs for Preſents at Court; who ſpends the morning in tyring good men with the repetition of ill Verſes, and in the afternoon lies ſtretcht out at length, in his open Gilt Coach, like the Image of Lazineſs drawn in Triumph through the City. — The Baggage laughs when I would have her weep.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, you have reaſon to be angry; but I've as much cauſe to laugh when I behold this Picture of a Suitor ſo deform'd that he ſeems ridiculous.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: You judge of a Man by his Picture; let me ſee it.— How the Devill have I baited my Hook at Court, that I have been ſix Months a fiſhing for this Cods-head? yet many have told me that D. John d' Alverad was a perſon highly eſteem'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If he had been tollerably handſome your command might be obey'd,

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p:
Well, however you ſhall promiſe me to uſe him civilly, and I'll then find a remedy for your grief.
Enter Lucilla, vail'd. But here comes a Lady that will not ſhew her ſelf, I wonder who let her in, and would not firſt ask, whether we would be viſible? Madam, without ſeeing your face, or inquiring your name, you may freely command me.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand, I expect no leſs from your civil reputation. I come to you for refuge, and beſeech you without any witneſs I may tell you my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You may Daughter retire. Exit Iſabell.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: I would I could ſo expreſs my griefs that you might find ſome excuſe for my faults. But if you could number my tears perhaps you would confeſs that my eyes have been ſufficiently puniſht by my Crimes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: This Stranger has no ill behaviour.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Sir, let me imbrace your knees, and not riſe from mine till I obtain that ſuccour which I hope you will afford me.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: This ſtile is ſomewhat Romantick. My fooliſh Daughter never read Romances, but, for my part, I eſteem Amadis and all ſuch antient and diſcreet Records of Love and Honour. Madam you ſeem not a perſon to whom a Gentleman ſhould refuſe any thing.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt then give you the trouble of knowing my Race, and of hearing my misfortunes. My Race you will eaſily know, for my dead Father often told me, that he had made a friendſhip wi • h you at Rome, and that you are a perſon both obliging and brave.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I owe him much for that Character, and ſhall be ready to pay the debt to you.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Sir, Burgos is the Town where I receiv'd my firſt being, and unfortunately the flames of Love. My Mother dy'd at my birth, and my Father deceaſ'd ſoon after her when he perceiv'd the misfortune of my love. His name was Diego d' Alverad. He bred me with great care and bounty, and he had much hope of my Infancy; but alas! it was a falſe hope. My Two Brothers were no leſs cheriſht by him, and I as much by them; with whom I happily liv'd. But oh, how love did change my deſtiny!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: A thouſand curſes take that Devil Love, it imbroyles us all.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: A Stranger who came to ſee the Triumphs at Burgos did in thoſe Turnements appear to have no equal. We firſt ſaw one another in an Aſſembly; I was courted by him, and did endure his Courtſhip, or rather I was charm'd by him. He pretended to love me; and I lov'd him, but now, Sir, let my tears ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sure all Lovers were born in April: they never mention Sun-ſhine without a ſhowr after it. This may teach me to marry my Daughter to ſome Gentleman whom ſhe does not love. But, Madam, pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p:
The reſt is fatal, Sir, and full of ſhame. Alas my fault depriv'd me of a Brother, and my afflicted Father ſoon dy'd after him. My paſſion had ſo overmaſter'd my reaſon, that I ſtill ador'd my unfaithfull Lover, whoſe return to Burgos I did two years vainly expect, and at laſt found that I was cruelly forſaken: and then I forſook my Kinred, and, curſing fatal Love, am hither guided by
madneſs to ſeek that falſe man whom more than juſtly I ought to hate.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Is not this ſufficient to teach Parents to marry their Daughters without any leaſt mention of love. Madam, how the Devil could you be couſen'd with love?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, he told me he would be faithful. But Women ſhou'd never believe that beauty can ſufficiently oblige the hearts of men, eſpecially if men be ſo handſome as to prevail on women.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I am glad Don John's Picture renders him ugly.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Oh Don Ferdinand! I am a fearful example for having too much believ'd a cruel Tyger, who triumphs over me, diſguiſing his name as falſely as his faith: a name which no man ſeems to know, yet I am certain he lurks hereabouts. To you I addreſs my ſelf as my laſt remedy, and I demand your ayd to find him out. I know the quality you bear about this place may apprehend him, and force him to do me reaſon.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I ſhall be one of Cupids Baylies, and watch to arreſt a man for debts of love.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: I'll not alledge my Father nor his memory, but by your own glory will conjure you, and not oblige you by any phraſe of flattery.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Madam, to be ſhort, I am your humble ſervant; and ſuch I have been ever to your Father, who did me the honour to call me Brother. Diſpoſe of all my power; my Daughter ſhall endeavour to aſſwage your griefs.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Your Nephew, Sir, deſires your ear for ſomething of importance.

sp.speaker: Ferd. to Lucill.
sp.p: Madam, my return ſhall be ſodain. Bettris lead her to my appartment, and admit my Nephew preſently.

The chance is odd that this Lady proves the Siſter of my elected Son-in-Law. I muſt preſent her to him if he will ſee her. My Nephew and I will joyn our powers to ſeek her Lover, and to do her Juſtice. Enter D. Lewis.
O dear Don Lewis, my brave Nephew, what brings you hither, how may I ſerve you?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Sir, a friend of mine has lately advertiſ'd me of a quarrel coming towards me, and I am come for your advice, who are a perfect Judge of Combats of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: If you can imploy no other whom you love more than me, nor that loves you more than I do, I'm at your ſervice. What is that Paper in your hand?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I'll read it to you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Do, for I have loſt my ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis
sp.p: reads.

The younger Brother of him whom you kill'd upon ſome love-accompts, departs from this place to day to goe where you are. I know not perfectly the occaſion, but am certain that to give you notice of it is not ill done by your Servant Don Pedro Oſſorio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Where did you incounter him who is ſlain?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: In Burgos.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Was he a Cavalier?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Yes, and my great Friend.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: In ſingle Combat?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: No, by miſtake, in the darkneſs of the night.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Tell me the manner of it.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: You remember the Triumphs at Burgos for the firſt Infante. A Friend of mine invited me thither to ſhew me the common valour of our Nation in the Joco de Toros. The night after the Triumph he led me to ſee the Ladies at a Ball, where I was conquer'd by a Beauty, and ſhe by me; but this great happineſs ſoon turn'd into a great misfortune.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well, Sir, proceed:

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I was allow'd the honour the next day to give her a viſit, lov d her ſincerely, and being one night together I heard an attempt to break open the dore. I ſaw her tremble and drew my ſword for her ſafety. She took the Candle and blew it out. The dore was open'd, and I was attacqu'd, and in the incounter, not having the uſe of my Eyes, there ſell at my Feet one mortally wounded; the darkneſs made my eſcape eaſie. But in the morning I was overwhelm'd with grief, being inform'd that the perſon ſlaine was Brother to my Miſtreſs, and the ſame intimate Friend, who invited me to Burgos.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Theſe are the effects of love, and yet my fooliſh Daughter will needs be in love before ſhe marry.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: My eſcape from Burgos was eaſie, becauſe I was not known in publick. You ſee the intelligence which is given me, and of what uſe your counſel may be in the affair. A Gent • eman is in ſearch of me, who is led hither by revenge. It were loſs of honour to avoid him, and it were cruelty to kill him. But ſome body knocks at your Gate. Knocking within.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: And rudely too. Who dares be thus inſolent?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O, Sir, give me a hundred Crowns for my good news.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Pray ſtay till they are told out, and give me the news firſt.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Where is my Miſtreſs? Her Suitor is below all over powder'd, and perfum'd. He ſeems a merry and innocent man, for he laughs at every thing as if he had no more cares than a Capuchin.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.p: Sir, it ſeems you have a deſign to marry my Couſin, and ſecretly.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis aſide.
sp.p: How am I wounded with this news!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Bid my Daughter come down. Make haſte.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You need not doubt my ſpeed when I'm to bring Lovers together. Exit.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: How ſhall I bear this perſecution?

sp.speaker: Ferd. aſide.
sp.p: I ſhall have uſe of all my underſtanding to get clear from the perplexity of my divided int'reſt. My Nephew has kill'd the Brother of him who is to marry my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.p: I ſhall grow mad.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Come Iſabella, we muſt prepare to meet your Suitor.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Or rather to meet death. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sancho, Todelet, in Don John's Habit; Don John in Todelets Habit.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I told you my Maſters name.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You did.

sp.speaker: D. John
sp.p: And does your Maſter know that he is here?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: He doth.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sure Don Ferdinand's detain'd by ſome important buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I hope when that's diſpatcht, Don John ſhall have the honour to kiſs his hands.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: He ſhall.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This Laconick Fool makes brevity ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Todelet.
sp.p: An Aſs for brevity ſake ſhould have cropt Ears and a bob'd Tail.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: My Maſter is arriv'd upon deſign of Allyance with yours, and I hope we, who are their Servants, may become a kin to one another by friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: 'Tis fit.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Your hand —

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Take it —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Good. They embrace.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Friend, you are a man of brevity. I would your Maſter were ſo too. Shall I not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: But (by your favour) in what quantity of time?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: A trice.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfiy'd: but have not yet ſatisfy'd for your diligence— I'm ſorry 'tis the faſhion for Gallants to carry no mony about 'em. Feels in his Pockets and finds no money.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: That's ill.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: But my Trunks are coming.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: That's good.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: If my Sumpter proves lame I ſhall borrow of your Maſter rather than be in debt to his man.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: He means to repreſent me firſt by ſhewing his bounty.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I grow impatient, and muſt be diverted. Friend, what is there here to ſee?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.p: The Houſe.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I uſe to ſpend my time in things of more importance. Todelet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Inquire if his Maſter be learned.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: He's ſo ſo.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Let's viſit his Library. Yet, now I think on't, I have had my head twice crackt with reaching down great Books from high Shelves. Well, 'tis ſtrange how ſince my childhood I ever lov'd huge great Books, and could read in 'em as eaſily as if they were but little.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This is to ſhew he is a man of learning.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Next to great Books I love intollerable long Letters in ſhort hand. If I had one here, you ſhould ſee me begin at Loving kind Friend, and in a moment, end at Yours as his own.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This ſhews him a man of buſineſs and of diſpatch too.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: This (I take it) is your Ante-chamber. The Floor is ſmooth, but ſomewhat bare: my Rooms at home are all matted.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: How like a dull Rogue he boaſts of his rich furniture.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: We uſe no Mats.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Why Friend?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: For fear —

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Of Fleas.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Alas, poor things! they do no harm, we never uſe to kill 'em.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Now he ſhews himſelf a man of mercy.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: In this Country —

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Well, ſpeak your mind.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Fleas uſe —

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: To bite.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: We have abundance of 'em, but not a man of mine does ever feel 'em.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: That's ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Family feeds well, and then they ſleep ſo ſoundly that Puneſes cannot wake 'em. Lord, how I love to hear my ſervants ſnore after dinner.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Now he ſhews his Hoſpitality.

sp.speaker: Sancho to D. John.
sp.p: We ſhall all grow fat when your Maſter keeps houſe here: yet you, me-thinks, are ſomewhat lean.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I thought this fellows Tongue had been wound up like a Clock to regular ſtops, but now it ſtruck above Twelve words. Sir I may truſt you, who are hereafter to be my faithfull Friend. The chief reaſon why I am not fat is, moſt eſpecially, becauſe I am in love with Three of our Neighbours Maids.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Three?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I confeſs I am unfortunate in it.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You are.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: My Grandmother was a Poeteſs, and a great obſerver of love, and was wont to put her thoughts into Verſe, which were very pithy.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And ſhort.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: She wrot according to her own Cyze, for ſhe was a very ſhort Woman. Shall I repeat?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Pronounce.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: A Ruddy Sanguine Man.
Grows quickly pale and wan,
And is by Love undone
Even when he loves but one.
But I am much miſtaken
If Two will not make
As lean as a Rake
A Lover fat as Bacon.

div.stage: Enter D. Ferd. D. Lewis, Iſabel, Bettris.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Don John, firſt for your Fathers ſake, then for your own I muſt embrace; nay let me bind you cloſe to my heart.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, you may claſp me as hard as you pleaſe, for I'll aſſure you I am very ſound both Spring and Fall.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd aſide.
sp.p: Sound? that's an odd aſſurance from a Son in Law.
Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I knew that before, Sir; which may give y • u a ſmall taſte of my underſtanding; pray ſpeak only things that are neceſſary; for I love few words.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: This Son in Law will prove wiſe.

div.stage: Iſabella draws Todelets Picture and looks on it aſide.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: The Painter has done him no wrong.

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.p: Her Beauty exceeds all that any Pencil can deſcribe.

div.stage: D. John looks on Iſabella's Picture aſide.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Father in Law looks as gravely as an Owl at Noon pearcht over a Church-Porch.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I fear my Son in Law is not very eloquent, he ſpeaks in private between the Teeth.

sp.speaker: Iſab. aſide.
sp.p: Was ever deformity copy'd with more exact proportion to the Original.

sp.speaker: Tod. to Iſab.
sp.p: I can ſee you through my Fingers and know you at firſt ſight by the Picture you ſent me.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He's one of thoſe ſubtle Spies who peeps through the Keyhole when the dore is open.

sp.speaker: Tod. to Iſabell.
sp.p: You think me a very deſperate man.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: For coming near ſo bright a Sun as you a • e without a Paraſol, Umbrellia, or a Bondgrace.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You intend to be very witty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I tell you agen, my bright Sun, not one among a thouſand would venture his complexion ſo near you as I do. But what care I for being tann'd▪

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: ' • is, but fleaing the old skin, and when your cheeks are raw the crimſon will appear preſently.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That Damſel is too pert. Dear Chuck of my Cheeks, you ſhould keep theſe Paraqueeto's in a Cage. How many of 'em have you? Slight, I think I'm left alone Todelet! where are all my People? Todelet?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My heart beats too much at ſight of my Miſtreſs. If I faint with love be ſure to hold me up.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I ſhall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lady, you ſay nothing: but I'm glad you are ſilent, for if you ſhould ſhew as much w • t as you do beauty, I were a dead man. Todelet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: To drive away the ſorrows of love I prithee break a Jeaſt or two, or tell my Miſtreſs ſome of mine to cure her melancholy.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: My Father has made a rare choice. This extraordinary Fool is only fit for Chriſtmas.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand, doe you alwayes ſerve for a Skreen to your Daughter?

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.p: Unlucky Rogue! what Devil taught thee to ask that?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: That queſtion is not very civil.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Thoſe that are angry may ſhew their teeth; but let them be ſure that they be ſharp.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Sir, no man will doubt yours.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Thoſe who dare doubt mine may meet me — at dinner; and after dinner may walk a turn in the Field. It may be wholſome for ſome, but for others it may prove dang'rous.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: He grows angry.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: May not a man ſee a ſnip of her face? I pray, Lady of my lips, blink on me a little with one eye. Don Ferdinand, let ſome body bring her near me; or at leaſt ſhew me her Hand, or her Arme, or a little of her Leg.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This courſe Villain has been bred in a Bu • cher-Row.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: My Daughter had reaſon. My Son in Law is a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lord, how nice they are of their Brides in this Country! any where elſe I might e'r this have had a dozen kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: How I am vext at his want of breeding!

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Father in Law you muſt pardon me. I am a little boyſtrous, but I am very loving. My dainty Duckling may I know what guſt you take in having the honour to ſee me?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: That's civilly askt.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: O impertinent Son in Law.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: They laugh. I ſhall be loth to marry in ſo fooliſh a Kinred as have no more wit than to laugh at me. Don Ferdinand, pray call for a Chair: you are ill ſerv'd; but I will vouchſafe to reach one my ſelf.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. aſide.
sp.p: I ſay agen my Son in law is a very Coxcomb. Bettris reach a Chair.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sweet Syrrop of my Soul, pray tell me, do you wear Chopeens? in truth if you do not, you are of a reaſonable good ſtature, and worthy of me.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: An excellent good Complement.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That young man is given to prating. Tell me, my bright Sun, do you ſhine on him?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: He is my Couſin Germain.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I pronounce the third time that my Son-in law is a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This Couſin Germain revives my jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lady, have you never an Ear-picker about you; there's ſomething tickles me within, and I broke mine with picking my teeth. What all laughing agen? Lady, you laugh ſcurvily! you laugh like a Munky that has ſtoln cher • ies; he, he, he, he!

sp.speaker: D. Lewis to Iſabel.
sp.p: Couſin you do not ſatisfie the Gentleman, he askt you e'n now how you did reliſh the honour of ſeeing him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs I never ſaw his Equal both in body and mind.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Madam, every one ſays as much of me. But the twenty thouſand Crowns, are they ready? Let's diſpatch the Marriage.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: How, D. John? you are mercenary.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Thoſe who believe it are very deſperate. But would I could meet 'em in Alverad.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: In Alverad! Had you not a Brother, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Yes, whom a baſe Murderer kill'd in the dark.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: If Don John could find the Murderer he would eat his heart; but the Coward hides himſelf.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: This Groom is very impudent. But, Friend, I have been told —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: What have you been told, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: That it was meerly by miſchance.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: He ly'd that told you ſo; it was treachery.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis. to Iſabel.
sp.p: Do you obſerve his ſawcineſs?

sp.speaker: Iſabel.
sp.p: Methinks his anger has ſomething gracefull in it.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Then you allow his inſolence?

sp.speaker: Iſabel.
sp.p: He ſhews no meanneſs in his courage.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis to D. John.
sp.p: I ſhall find you.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: You may, for I ſhall never avoid you.

sp.speaker: Iſabel.
sp.p: O pitty hide thine eyes! how canſt thou ſee ſuch Gallantry in ſuch a low condition?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Wer't not in this place, I ſhould make you ſilent.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My man is almoſt as valiant as my ſelf, but a little raſh.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Uncle, ſhall I indure this from that Groom?

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I charge you be diſcreet. Her's a fair beginning of a marriage.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My dear Dumpling let 'em quarrel; and let us talk and be witty and ſell Bargains.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, you ha' not yet ſeen the Houſe.
Bettris make haſte, open the Gallery. Nephew, I conjure you to make uſe of your diſcretion. Come Gentlemen, what do you ſtay for?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I love the down-right familiarity of Alverad, and hate Complement.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: That's for ſaving of time.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: We often (out of heartineſs and haſte) ſalute Ladies with our hats on.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Do you ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Yes, and take 'em by the hand without the tedious Ceremony of pulling off our Gloves.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: 'Tis true, time is a precious thing and ought to be ſav'd. Son-in-law it becomes you. Exeunt Omnes.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Retire to the Garret over that Chamber where I muſt hide your Maſter, and there you muſt lie cloſe.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I ſhould lie cloſer if you were with me.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Certainly you men are very cold Creatures: you are alwaies wiſhing for ſomething to keep you warme.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Ah Bettris, a Garret without a Chimney is a cold habitation. But if you were near me —

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I • now but one Hoop in the world can bind us cloſe together.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: A Wedding-Ring.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: That's a ſtrong Hoop indeed, and will hold out long. I have no Land nor Houſe; and though there are many Houſes in Town, yet thoſe Tenants never get much furniture who begin with a Cradle. I am not rich enough to marry.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That's ill news, but I will tell you better.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I prithee do.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: At night when the Maſters are abed the Men ſhall have a Sack-Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And ſhall they be very merry with the Maids?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Yes, unleſs the Men be in love, for then, alas, they'll do nothing but ſigh.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: What Lady is that whom your Miſtreſs does conceal?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I know her not. Sancho does mannage that deſign; her Maid is his Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Shall ſhe be with us?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He has invited her.
You wiſh my Company and inquire after her. None but a cold Bedfellow would have two Warming-Pans.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Signior Sancho, there is nothing more Medc'nal againſt the Conſumption of Love than a Sack-Poſſet. But ſhall I be at it?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I am much oblig'd to you for the Invitation.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You are.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I hope I may have leave to ſeal an acquaintance on this fair Gentlewomans hand?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You may. D. John ſalutes Laura.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to make uſe of your authority.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I Pray give me leave to ſalute Miſtreſs Betteris.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Doe.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: The favour ought to go round. I hope I ſhall not be a ſtranger to your Miſtriſs.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: No. Stephano ſalutes Laura.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Your authority extends ſo far as to make me likewiſe known to Miſtreſs Betteris.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: It doth. D. John ſalutes Betteris.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Well, we ſhall be all happy when our Lords and Ladies are aſleep. There is nothing ſo ſweet as Midnight and Sack-Poſſet. Is there Signior Sancho?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What can be ſweeter in this bitter World?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Buſs and Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: My Lady calls me. Let every one haſten to their appointed ſtations.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: The next time when our Maſters go to bed early we muſt be contented to ſit up late.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Alas! we Servants are miſerable. We muſt be fain to watch when they ſleep.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Pray let us meet chearfully, and with ſhort ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And long ſpoons. Exeunt all ſeveral waies but Don John.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: I have more light to lead my jealouſie.
And now muſt ſeek the man to whom Revenge
Is yet indebted for my Brother's Blood;
Then where my vain, imprudent Siſter lives,
And where her perjur'd Friend. Well, it grows ſtrong
In my belief that Iſabella's Couſin
Is he whom I diſcern'd in the Balcone;
Oh Iſabell! be wiſe as thou art fair;
Turn not my love to dangerous deſpair.

div.head: ACT. III.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: URge me no more; the lot is caſt.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: In troth Don John is much beholding to you. You have forſaken his Siſter, kill'd his Brother, and now pretend to his Wife.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: My hope relies on my perſeverance, and on Betteris, and on thee; on my Uncle, on Iſabella, and on my ſelf: I rely much too on the rudeneſs of Don John's behaviour, but moſt of all on the civility of my Goddeſs Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O, Sir, is it you?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: None but a Maid, who loves to meet men in the dark would ask that queſtion with her eyes open.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You are ſtill drawing the Fools weapon: I pray put up your Tongue. I come not to you, but to your Maſter.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Dear Bettris, tell me a little of the Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Would y • u have but a little when much may be ſpoken? He din'd, and did eat till his doublet grew ſo narrow that 'twas dangerous to ſit near him; for his buttons flew about like a volley of ſhot, and after dinner he retir'd to a dirty Entry, where he ſlept on a Bench and ſnor'd in conſort, like three fat Carriers in one Bed. But I'll tell you what paſs'd beſides.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: My poor Bettris!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: My poor D. Lewis!

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: My fortune I expect from thee.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: And I mine from you: but you have yet proceeded no further than promiſe: yet that's ſufficient to one who abhorres intereſt.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I prithee ask my Man if I have not left my Gold under my Bolſter; and whether I am not to morrow to receive four hundred Duckets?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Well, well! he • r me in few words. Don Ferdinand your Uncle has chaff'd himſelf into a Fevor: he would fain be diſingag'd. Your dear Iſabella is more vext than he. Now is the time or never: you muſt endeavour to ſee her, and give her as many promiſes as thoſe m • ke who intend to keep none. Write her Poetical Letters, and be ſure not to leave out her Lillies nor her Roſes: you muſt weep, ſigh, and pull off your Periwig, that you may tear your own hair: tell her you'l cut your own throat, or at leaſt that you know an eaſie way to hang your ſelf.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Concerning that, Betteris, you may ſafely paſs your word for me.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: If the inſolence of paſſion will not prevail you muſt reſume your modeſty, whine civily, and only wiſh your ſelf dead; and be not amaz'd when ſhe grows impatient. What, you ſmile at this good counſel?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: No, but it ſeems a little new.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: The p • actice of it is as antient as the Love-Tricks in Troy. But I have ſtayd too long. Beſhrew my heart for my kindneſs to you. Goe, Sir, ſteal through the Garden dore. Farewel, Sir, and I pray give your Man leave to ſhift your Trenchers before they are empty. He looks leaner than Lent.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Farewell falſe money.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Remember that I clipt your beard by Moon-ſhine with the Gard'ners great Sheers when you lay a ſleep like a dead Perdu in the Arbour. O, y'are a proper Watchman to attend Lovers.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: My Beard Miſtreſs Marmalad.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Yes, when my Ladies little Dog ſmelt you out, by the broken meat in your Pocket.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Well, I'll marry thee for a Month, that I may get authority to ſwadle thee for having no Portion.. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I'll rather die of naked poverty than break my word.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Dear Father!

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You are a Fool, and all that you can hope, is that I may deferr your Marriage a few dayes. But was ever any buſineſs ſo incumber'd? My Son-in law is offended, and my Nephew being the cauſe of it, I ought to be ſo too. Shall I abandon one and joyn with the other? I owe my ſelf to one by blood, and to the other by honor.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: It ſeems, Sir, 'twas Don Lewis that kill'd his Brother.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yes, and to increaſe the perplexity, the Siſter of Don John implores me againſt him: how can I, in honour, refuſe to aſſiſt her? and to day my Nephew tells me, he has need of my advice againſt a man whom he has doubly offended, and that man muſt be my Son-in-law. Head hold out one day, and ſplit not during this ſtorme of bus'neſs. Farewell, I'll go taſte my Son-in-Law. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
And I'll go weep. O Heav'n! to what a Brute am I condemn'd? Was not my averſion a ſufficient torment without giving me a new affliction by another paſſion? Was't not enough to be unhappy by the addreſs of the Maſter, but I muſt love his Man? Ah, my ſtarres hate mee too much, when they make me love one whom I dare not name to my own ear. Muſt I adore him who never can be
mine, and at the ſame time abhorre the Perſon for whom I am decreed? A third Evil is joyn'd to t'other two. Don Lewis, whom I hate, loves me. At once I hate, and fear, and am in love. O who can deliver me from this entangled deſtiny?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: 'Tis I, O charming Iſabella! that will deliver you, and diſingage you f • om Don John: for ſince Don Lewis, whom you have deſpiſ'd, is now admitted to your favour, your breath contains my Rivals deſtiny. Proſcribe him with one word, and, with this ſword I am his Executioner.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns! dare you propoſe a miſchief of this bloody ſhape? Be gon, unhappy Wretch: thou art unworthy of that pity, which, to the injury of Juſtice, thy name and blood being mine, makes me afford thee. How canſt thou love me if thou thinkſt me capable even but to hear thy black deſign? Fly, fly to Burgos with thy perfidiouſneſs, and there go act thy Tragedies. Go and deceive the Siſter of the Brother thou haſt ſlain.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Hah! if ever —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Peace, peace, thou blackeſt of ill-ſpirits, or I will fill the Houſe with exclamations.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Pray ſpeak low; Don Ferdinand and the Son-in-law are upon the ſtairs, they may hear you. How ſhall we ſhift Don Lewis away, for Don John's man is in the next Chamber. I would he would ſhew his extraordinary diſcretion and good meen ſome where elſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: If I durſt appear —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Keep your expedients, for your own uſe; 'tis I that am concern'd now.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: If his angry Man —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, he ſeems not one whoſe anger may be tam'd with threatning. Bettris!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, I tremble a • l over. What think you if I awhile conceal Don Lewis in your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Diſpoſe of him any where, provided he be far from my ſight.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Madam, be froward then a while; and raiſe your voice, and call me bold, and impud • nt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I underſtand you. Exeunt Don Lewis, Bettris. Iſabella ſpeaks loud.
You ſay Don John is not handſome.
What, he diſpleaſes you? you'l mend his making, I like him as he is.
I would my Father heard you. Y'are inſolent, be gone!

div.stage: Enter D. Ferdinand, Tod. and D. John.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: We hear you Daughter. You are angry.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis only for a trifle which my Maid has loſt.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Humph. This will not paſs; for, though I'm ſtuft in the head, yet I can blow my Noſe as well as another to ſmell things out. No, no, I ſee I may make love long enough before you ſmicker at me. You may e'en keep your Portion, I ſhall find my Land in the old Place.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How, Sir, will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: When two or three have ſufficiently forſworn themſelves to you, then you'll tuck up your Petticoats and follow me to Alverad.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This dull Rogue, for fear he ſhould not be unlucky enough to do me miſchief, makes it up with inundations of folly.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Son-in-law, me-thinks your behaviour is a little out of faſhion, and, in plain terms, you want wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Father-in-law, this is but a trick of mine to try her love. I'll ſound her heart though it lies as deep as her belly.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Nay they are pollitick in your Province. But if my Daughter be thoroughly anger'd—

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Theſe are a kind of witty f • umps of mine like ſelling of Bargains; I'll come off well enough. Let's walk into the Gallery.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: For fear this extraordinary Brute ſhould find out his Siſter, I'll leave him in the hands of his Miſtreſs. Stay here a while, Sir, with my Daughter • . I muſt part from you one moment upon a preſſing occaſion. Exit. D. Ferd.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p:
My dainty Dears your Father being gone, and here being none but Friends left, you may ſwear to me in private how much you
love me. I'll ſay nothing to any body. I can keep decrets; for when I'm askt what a clock 'tis, I never tell for fear men ſhould take me for a blab.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, I'll deal f • eely with you. I was never in love till to day: I had formerly an averſion to it, diſdain was all my paſſion. Believe me, Sir, the flame of love is only known to me ſince your arrival. But ſince my love can meet none equal to it, ſhould it rejoyce when it incounters yours? No, Sir, to the contrary; I'm in extreme pain to ſee you love me, and that I muſt likewiſe love.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Humph! if I had not a great deal of wit • I ſhould hardly underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Your paſſion equals not the price of mine,
Though what is with you, and to you belongs.
Is e'n all that which I do moſt adore,
Yet in you is all that which I abhorre.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Hah! what belongs to me, and is with me, you adore, and what is in me, you abhorre. Lady to ſuch dark ſayings as theſe, the antient Philoſophers of Alverad make anſwer in a ſubtle queſtion; which is, Ridle my Ridle what's this?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Sir, I muſt juſtifie my meaning to you,
You doubt my flame, but, Sir, I ſay agen
I lo • e that which is yours, and love it much.
In ſeeing it I altogether ſee
The object of my love, and then I burn and tremble,
Burn with deſire, and tremble with my fear.
Y • u cauſe at once my joy and ſorrow too,
What evil can there be more ſtrange and rare?
Which when I hide I then almoſt declare.
If I, to eaſe my pain, my mind reveal
I danger bring to that which I would heal.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: She has wit prevailing as her beauty, but 'tis myſtical.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: If men ſwear they are bewitcht when they are in love, then I, being in love, may ſay you are a Witch, eſpecial • y becauſe you ſpeak things as hard to be underſtood as Charms.

sp.speaker: D. John
sp.p: O Love, why art thou born with the diſeaſe of jealouſie. All curſes meet upon Don Lewis.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You, my Serving man, come nearer and make love for me, and afterwards we'll do it by turns.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: But Sir —

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: How Coxcomb! perhaps you would give me counſel. Am not I your Maſter? does any man know ſo much as you the love I bear her, and who then can better tell her of it? That's fine y'faith; belike I want underſtanding to direct what's fit to be done.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Madam, I muſt obey ſince I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: The Fellow is afraid! Madam, he wants a little breeding, yet I have been a Pattern to him above ſeven years.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sure he has been an ill obſerver then.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ſay advance! and court her handſomly, whilſt I go to the Gate, and conſult with the Porter how to ſcatter a little Gold amongſt the Servants to ſhew my bounty and make Friends.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How ſhall I then get Don Lewis out: curſe on this Fool. Sir you muſt needs ſtay: for if th'Original be gone you'll have an ill account of the Copy: 'tis a hard thing to draw Love well.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: If ſhe ſhould be now really in love with me, D. John courts her in whiſpers. then I were in a fine caſe. My Maſter wants no Cudgels; and I ſhould be the moſt beaten Bridegroom that ever medled with more than his match. Let me conſider. Hah, Maſter Valet de Chambre. Have I put you there to do nothing. You talk in her ear, Sirrah, either ſpeak out, or keep farther off.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir, I'm aſham'd to ſpeak loud, your Worſhip will but laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l: No doubt of that. But I've a mind to laugh, for to ſay truth
I am afraid of ſighing. She's damnable handſome! aſide.
When Love's afraid, do not that fear deſpiſe;
Flame trembles moſt when it doth higheſt riſe;
And yet my love may juſtly be diſdain'd,
Since you believe it from a Lover feign'd.
I am not here that which I ought to be,
I ſerve, yet from all bonds but yours am free.
Though Player-like I feign my Maſters part,
Yet real jealouſie affl • cts my heart.
For whilſt his feigned Rival I appear,
I then another real Rival fear.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: This language has more myſtery than mine.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p:
A real Rival. That's I, or Don Lewis. A pox o'theſe intoxicating
Riddles; can any man ſtand ſtill when charms make his head turn round? I'll hear no more of 'em. Avant Todelet! thou art a fooliſh Conjurer! Preſto, be gon!

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Is your Worſhip in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I've a thought in my head worth the weight of it in gold. Hah! now I have loſt it. Sweet Noſegay of my Noſe, when I remember you I alwaies forget my ſelf: or elſe 'tis that Baggage, Bettris, which tranſports me; for, to ſay truth, ſhe runs in my mind too. My Serving-man be gone.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I muſt obey you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l: Youl'd fain ſtay to ſing loth to depart. Why when I ſay! —
sp.stage: D. John goes and ſtands cloſe at the dore.
sp.l: I will be left alone with my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: How, Sir, alone? What will the Servants ſay?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: what can they ſay when I think fit to be private?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'm ſure Bettris will take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: That's true, for Bettris likes me ſo well, that if ſhe ſee us making love it may coſt her half her life. But that's all one, I love you only.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Yes and Bettris alſo.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Faith Lady I am free of making my beſt parts known. What, I have made you jealous of me? That's another of my Politick Love-tricks. I'm grown ſo ſubtle that the Devil will be afraid of me But let him ſhun me then: for take one time with another, he does me more hurt than good.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: But, Sir, what mean you? why muſt we be alone?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: to ſhew my confidence: for let 'em ſay what they will, I dare truſt my ſelf with you. I have not ſeen the Balconee yet. Let's goe take the Air.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: There is no wind ſtirring.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: What new fi • k of folly has enter'd into the Raſcals head? I muſt obſerve him.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Come along ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me, Sir. I'll not ſtir from hence.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: How, not ſtir? my Dear, you muſt know I'm very chollerick —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: What drawn by force? y'are inſolent.

div.stage: He offers to reach her hand.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Duck you are ſqueamiſh. Lord, what diff'rence there is in People? you ſee I am not ſo —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Rude wretch forbear! wer't not for that patience which is ordain'd me by my Father, I'ld tear your eyes out with theſe hands.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: With thoſe hands? you'ld pleaſe me more, if you would let me kiſs 'em.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Sir, you are mad, and would make me ſo too. Is this the bruitiſh Courtſhip of your Province? Exit.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: O Villain! you would preſume to kiſs her hand.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange thing! to ſee how men may be miſtaken.
'Twas ſhe, Sir, would preſume to kiſs mine.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Slave! you are in jeaſt then, and you think I'm ſo too.
I'll make you repent your impudence — D. John ſtrikes him.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, why Maſter, Pray Sir?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Pattern of Rogues! thou Gallows climber!

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Nay pray, Sir, do not puniſh behind; all that I ſaid to her, was face to face.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: 'Tis anger, and grows loud. Pray heav'n they have not found the miſchievous Don Lewis.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Dogg! you may be glad that my reſpect to her preſence ſtops my fury.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Now ſhe's here, If I ſhould ſtrike him he dares not diſcover himſelf. Todelet aſſaults D. Jo • n.
Ill teach you to ſpeak ill of Iſabella. Is ſhe but reaſonable handſome? Hah! —

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Ah do not ſtrike him Sir. Be not cruel to your Servant.

div.stage: Tod. ſpeaks low and faſt to Don John.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt counterfeit your perſon to the life, you uſe to kick too. I have a great mind to give you a t • ſte of my foot, that I may reſemble you thoroughly.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Be leſs in earneſt when you counterfeit, or I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Rude man! what has he done to you?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Theſe are chollerick heats which paſs away, Lady. If I ſhould kick him I could not hurt him; he's all oak behind, meer Wanſcote-board. We who have tender toes are ill provided for tough Bumms. D. John ſpeaks ſoftly to him agen.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sirrah! were not ſhe here—

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: He ſits too much on bare Benches and Joynt-ſtools. I muſt buy Cuſhions for him to make him ſofter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: But how has he deſerv'd this uſage?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: He ſaid your beauty could not kill a man a mile off.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Was that all, Sir? If he hates me, alas! he knows not yet he is ingrateful.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I can no longer deferre it. I muſt diſcover my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Sirrah, begon. Expect nothing from me but a Cudgel to meaſure your bones. Lady, may I not ſtrip him naked, and keep his clothes now I turn him away?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: O no, Sir, If I have any credit with you, turn him not away.

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.p: Did ever Rogue uſe his Maſter thus, or Maſter ſo fooliſhly truſt the diſcretion of his Man?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Lilly white Lamb! you are too mercifull. I cannot ſtay near you upon ſuch cowardly termes. I'll into the Garden a while. We men of mettal uſe to walk a turn to cool our courage. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab. aſide.
sp.l: I bluſh, and know not what to ſay. Is love
A crime when it uſurps a Monarchs power
In giving dignity to that which it eſteems?
You were e'r while another perſon and to Don John.
Did repreſent Don John; and then I ſpoke
Some words which you might miſinterpret to
Be Love. But, you are now poor Todelet,
And ought to alter your opinion of
My paſſion ſince your perſon's chang'd.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Madam, if I had reaſon to believe
That you eſteem'd Don John, I ſhould grow weary of
My being as I am, and repreſent agen
The perſon that I was.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Sure you eſteem him much, ſince you can take
Such pleaſure in aſſuming of his Love.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Next my deſire of Heav'n I wiſh Don John.
Made happy by your love with Hymens rites.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I'll leave you till you learn to ask of heav'n.
A better deſtiny for me, that ſo I may
Be taught to make an equal wiſh for you.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Her love does ſtill grow darker, yet I ſee,
By too much light my cauſe of Jealouſie. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Don John, your Country-Lover, is gone into the Town to learn civility. He needs not ſtay long, for he may be taught it in the ſtreet by every Mule he meets.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Did you ſee him go out?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, he is not found about the Houſe; and I may now releaſe Don Lewis from his confinement.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Be ſure you do it preſently; and then make haſte to find me in the Garden. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I ſaw juſt now the weeping Lady. She's unluckily broke looſe too. I would we were well rid of theſe fooliſh Lovers. Sure common underſtanding has left the World. Young people cannot meet privately but they muſt needs fall in love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange Don Ferdinand ſhould uſe me thus. Is this protection when he ſtrait abandons me? He told me, he would return in a moment; and then (as if grown weary of civility, and of lending me his Chamber for ſhelter) he went perhaps to divert himſelf in the Town. I heard juſt now a noiſe like the confuſion of a quarrel. This is an ill ſign of my ſecure retreat. I muſt proceed in order to my ſafety; and yet I ought t'advertiſe them before I go. Sure this is Iſabella's Chamber; the Dore is open; I'll in, and take my leave of her. Enter D. Lewis
Hah! I diſcern a man, and I cann't avoid him.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I hope my friend Bettris (whom I have bound to me w • th the ſtrings of my Purſe) does mean to make this Chamber my Lodging. O dear Iſabella! whither would you run ſo faſt?

How, will you not vouchſafe to hear me? Alas! allow me but one
word. You have reproacht my love as ctiminal; thinking ſome other Beauty has poſſeſt my heart. Have I not ſworn, that ſhe who does pretend to it had but the promiſes of my pitty? and ſince I ſaw her at Burgos, I never did retain her in my thought?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! I have not patience to hear more. She opens her Vail. Falſe man! behold her now: For I am ſhe who too much has lov'd thee, and whom thou never lov'dſt. She, whoſe fatal and unexperienc'd heart too ſoon believ'd thy many Oaths. She, who does hate thee now, and will proclaim thy perjuries. She, whom thou call'dſt thy Soul and Queen, is now without a Brother, without her honour, and is leſs provided for than Birds blown off to Sea by Tempeſts.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Hear me but ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: No Traitor, no. Thy former perjuries have ſtopt my ears ſo much that I can hear no more. Help ho! help!

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, give me then leave to ſwear, and you ſhall ſoon be ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Soul without faith! Canſt thou agen expect belief? Help ho! help!

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: This grief is loud, and 'tis a womans voice.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! whom do I ſee?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Hah! Is not that my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Lucilla aſide.
sp.p: I call for help, and Heav'n has ſent deſtruction in a Brother.

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.l: My eyes cannot miſtake. She is my Siſter;
And th'other is the object of my jealouſie.
I have enough of anger for 'em both.
