sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: He carries miſchief in his Eyes, but ſeems
In doubt, on which of us he ſhould direct it firſt.

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.l: I am too certain of my Siſters crime,
But have not ſuch ſufficient proofs as may
Allow my jealouſie juſt leave to be
Reveng'd on him; I'll then begin with her. O thou
Unhappy, wicked woman! —

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.l: If I am wicked think me then
More fit to have ſome time for prayer.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: Hold! hold! I'll undertake her quarrel,
Though with that voice which brought thee hither ſhe
Was calling for revenge on me. But tell
Me by what title thou pretend'ſt to have
Authority to puniſh her?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I ought to do it.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: That's inſolence. A • t thou not a Servant?
D. John's my Maſter, and his honour's mine.

sp.speaker: Lucilla aſide.
sp.l: My ruine was prepar'd by ſome deſign.
Elſe wherefore ſhould my Brother hide himſelf
In this diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: Shall I indure to be affronted twice by him
Who ſerves my equal? — Lucilla endeavors to go out.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Hah! Are you going? ſtay! who brought you to
This Houſe? and wherefore did you call for help?

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: You ſhall know all. I enter'd in this Chamber to ſee Iſabella, where I found this man; but cannot tell for what intent he there did hide himſelf. I then cry'd out at the ſurpriſe, and tremble ſtill —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Enough! My jealouſie is apt to credit his offence.
I'll ſhut the Dore — Goes backward and ſhuts the Dore.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: My fear will kill me to prevent your cruelty.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Don Lewis I ſhall give you cauſe to ſhew your valour—

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I think it honour'd when 'tis us'd in her defence, but it deſerves a nobler tryal than your hand can make—

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.l: Oh fatal hour! how many deaths ſhall I endure?
My perjur'd Lover is yet kind when he
Does ſtrive to reſcue me. a noiſe of knocking within.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: The People of the Houſe will force the Dore.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: No matter, Sir. Let us diſpatch —

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. within.
sp.p: Let's force our paſſage, and break thorough.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: I'm counſell'd both by fear and love to open it.

sp.speaker: D. John ſpeaks low to Lucilla.
sp.p: Stir not to let them in; for if by thee I am diſcover'd —

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: Ah! Don Ferdinand! call all your Servants to your ayd.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: Proceed not in your fury, for by death
I ſwear, that he who does not ſheath his ſword,
Ingages me againſt him. Oh what ſtrange
Unlucky wonders meet to day t'amaze
And ruine me? Nephew, who put you here?
Ah! Lucilla, who diſcover'd you? And you, ſpeaks to D. John.
What Devil urges you? who ſince you came into
My Houſe have ſpent no minute but in quarrels.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Hear me, and you ſhall ſtrait know all.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: No, let me ſpeak! for I can better tell
It, Sir, than he. But I muſt firſt demand
If Lucilla did not in your Houſe conceal her ſelf?
And likewiſe if Don Lewis be not your near Kinſman?

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: The one and th'other too is true.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: And is't not reaſon that a Servant, Sir,
Should own an int'reſt in his Maſters honour?

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: That cannot be deny'd.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Then, Sir, obſerve if I am wrong'd.
I enter'd here, urg'd by Lucilla's cryes.
She found (as I believe, by accident)
Don Lewis in this Chamber where your Daughter lodges.
I in Lucilla ſaw the ſignes of a ſurpriſe.
'Tis evident to reaſon that he was hidden here all day;
For I have ſo obſerv'd all paſſage to the ſtreet
That it was hard for him to ſcape my Eyes.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis aſide.
sp.l: This reaſoning does appear too much refin'd,
For one of his courſe quality.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: My Maſter (who is to marry Iſabella,
And is Brother to Lucilla) muſt be offended
For his Miſtreſs or his Siſter: and it
Is likely he is wrong'd in both. My duty
Therefore is to finiſh my Revenge upon Don Lewis:

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: You are a man of rare diſpatch, who are
So ſure to finiſh that which is not yet begun. —

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Don Lewis, ſtay! Art thou mad? Stay Todelet! I prithee hold! This is the moſt perplext encounter that I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: He certainly is jealous for his Maſter.
Ah Todelet! let me intreat you to retire.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Madam, for your ſake I will preſcribe the means how
To deferre this quarrel; which is, that each engage his promiſe to me. You, Don Ferdinand, to render Lucilla in her Brothers power when he requires it. And you, Don Lewis, to make a tryall of your valour with Don John when he invites you to the Field.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I cannot without ſome torment, make promiſes of honour to one of thy low condition.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Don John, Sir, is no more a man than I am.
But if he fails to call you ſodainly
T'accompt, then you ſhall know whether I'm now,
Or may be made hereafter, fit to entertain your ſword.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: Enough we promiſe that which you deſire
Nay, Nephew, you are wont to yield to my Authority.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Well, Sir; your pleaſure is my Law; and here I give my promiſe.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: And I mine, that Don John ſhall juſtifie this quarrel.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.l: Nothing does then remain but that I ſeek
Your Maſter out to morrow.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Your journey, Sir, will not be farre to find him.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I'll be the foremoſt in the ſearch.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: You'll give me leave to follow you.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: That will be needfull, and without delay.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: This man is brave and loyal where he ſerves.
All is perplext. O Love lend me thy Clue
To lead me ſafe through this dark Labyrinth.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.l: Don Lewis now, does, after cruelty,
Shew ſome remorſe in my defence; and I
Am apt to think him penitent. But death
Will ſoon a period give to Love and Fear.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: To morrow early is th'appointed time to ſeek D. John.
Night now has drawn her Curtains cloſe. Let me
Conduct you to your ſeveral Beds, where ſleep
May quench that fire which makes your anger raſh.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: My precious rogue ſtole out to ſhun a quarrel.
His fear does ever make him ſick, and I
Shall find him drunk, for that's his conſtant cure. Exeunt.

div.stage: A Table ſpread with Linnen, Trenchers and Spoons are ſet out, and five Chairs.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: This Room ſtanding in the Garden, at diſtance from the Houſe, ſeems built for our purpoſe. Our happy hour is near. Dear Signior Sancho, ſhall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: As Maids?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Is there any Creature, except Man, that has the wit to be merry at Midnight?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: The Owle.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Y'are in the right. But what ſhall we have to make us rejoyce beſides a Sack-Poſſet?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Your words are ſeldome many, but alwaies pithy. Heark! there's ſomething ſtirring behind the Hanging.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: A Rat.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: If it be a Rat, then it has ſhooes on, for it treads hard, I rather fear 'tis the old Rat catcher your Maſter, that has caught us here in a Trap. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Tod within ſpeaks low.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: 'Tis a Mans voice, but he ſpeaks ſo low, that he ſeems more afraid than we are. Who is it?

sp.speaker: Tod. within.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: That were ſome anſwer to the queſtion, if we knew him that made it.

sp.speaker: Tod. within.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: To teſtifie that our being here is not for any harm you may know that we —

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Are we.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Well ſaid Signior Sancho; that's a valuable return of intelligence from us for what he gave of himſelf.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l:
Nay, if you name Signior Sancho.
Enter Todelet.
Don John may appear.

sp.speaker: Steph. aſide to Sancho.
sp.p: Our ſport is prevented. We may e'n hang up our Fiddles and our ſelves by 'em. Who ſent him hither?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: The Devil.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what occaſion brought you behind the Hanging?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I was led thither by Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Conſcience is a good Guide, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Don Ferdinands houſe is ſo full of quarrels as makes it very weariſome to one that has been already too much tir'd in the Field with wicked entertainments of honour.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhew both your valour and your reaſon.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: My Man Todelet is honeſt: but the Cuttlers of Toledo are not able to make ſwords enough to furniſh his Duels.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: If the old Roarer, Sathan, were young agen, my Man were fit to ſerve him.

sp.speaker: Steph. aſide to Sancho.
sp.p: The Man of blood which he mentions is your Gueſt to night, Signior Sancho, but not fit to be treated with a tame Sack-Poſſet. What ſhall we provide for him?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Raw Puddings.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Friends, to deal intirely with you, I ſtole hither to hide my ſelf partly out of Conſcience, but more out of diſcretion: for 'tis not fit a Gentleman of my Poſſeſſions, and near marriage, ſhould upon every peeviſh humour of his Servant venture his Eſtate and Body—

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Politick.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: But, Sir, Your Man is coming hither. We expect him in a moment.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I'll not ſee him till his fooliſh quarrels are ended.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you muſt pleaſe to retire agen behind the Hanging.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Agreed. My Friends, no words where I am.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Fy, no, Sir. But we ſhall ſtay here long. I hope you can have patience.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lord Friends, you do not yet underſtand my diſpoſition, for 'tis my patience which makes me ſteal from quarrels.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: You muſt be as little heard as ſeen. I hope you are not troubled with a Cold, nor apt to fall aſleep?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I would not have you cough.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Nor ſnore.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Friends, I ſay agen you know me not thoroughly. Tell not me of ſnoring: I dare ſnore with any man in Spain, and (hap what hap may) I'll venture agen behind the Hanging to hide my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, we know you are valiant.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And wiſe. Exit Todelet.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Sancho, our entertainment is provided, are your ſtomachs ready?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Then help to bring it to the Table. Enter Don John.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: In ſtate. Exit and brings in a great Baſon with a Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Signior Todelet you make good your promiſe, for yo • come in the very nick.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: In Poſſet time.

div.stage: Enter two young Women who aſsiſt in the Dance.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Two young marry'd Neighbours that long'd for Sack-Poſſet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Are your Ladies aſleep!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: They went to bed as early as Brides, and I hope will lye as long as Bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Then the Maids may be as merry as the Men.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And incounter a whole Pail of Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I'll meet as many quarrels as there be Drunkards in Dutchland rather than miſs a Sack-Poſſet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Ha! how comes he here?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Beſhrew your heart Signior Don John for ſtarting forth ſo ſodainly. 'Tis well we we • e all awake.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: If we had not been uſ'd to meet men in the dark it might have frighted us.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Ladies, without ſans ceremony, I'll ſit down firſt.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: D. John whiſpers Todelet.
sp.p: Villain be gone to my Chamber; you'll ſtill diſcover your courſe breeding.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Prithee forbear thy good manners to thy Maſter, ſit down, ſit down; I ſay ſit down. There are ſeaſons when Maſters may be familiar with their Men.

sp.speaker: D. John whiſpers Todelet.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Tod. whiſpers D John.
sp.p: I had rather you ſhould cut my throat than couſen my belly.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Villain, haſt thou the impudence to ſtay?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lord what adoe here is with civilities out of ſeaſon: once more I charge thee to ſit down, and I give thee leave to be familiar.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Rogue! to morrow will come.

sp.speaker: Todelet.
sp.p: Still over-mannerly! Ladies pray take your ſpoons. This Coxcomb my Man is ſo troubleſome with his untimely reſpects.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: You will not ſtir then?

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Prithee put thy hat on. Ladies, when I am at home and a little in drink, I often ſit with my ſervants.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, having my Maſters leave I will preſume on yours.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe the Poſſet is very hot, but Coragio is the word. 'Tis but the ſpoiling of a few good teeth. I'll venture at it.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Hold, I will firſt taſte—'Tis as hot as if they had ſtrew'd it with parcht Pepper inſtead of Cinnamon. He ſputters as if his mouth were burnt.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Stay! ſtay!

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Why Signior Sancho?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Stirr it — They all ſtirr and then eat together.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Ladies you eat too faſt.

div.stage: D. John riſes and whiſpers Todelet again.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Dog! Shew more civility, and do not diſgrace the perſon whom you counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I tell thee 'twill not make me ſick. I have been uſ'd to abundance of Poſſet. This good natur'd Fool takes ſuch care of my health.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Signior Todelet pray ſit down agen and take care of your own health; Poſſets are very wholſome.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir, The Cinnamon is good againſt wind.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Bettris, here's to your good health, and to yours Miſtreſs Laura.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: To both. Sancho ſlabbers his Beard.

sp.speaker: Tod
sp.p: Signior Sancho, that ſpunge your Beard, ſoaks up too much of the Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: It doth.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I only civily ſuppoſe it doth.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: All ſtay—

div.stage: He takes a huge knife out of his Pocket, ſcrapes the Poſſet off from his Beard and then eats it.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Who will pledge the Founders health?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Let it come. I am your Man.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: You are ſo; but a very ſawcy one: you uſe to talk and give counſell over your liquor.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Your Noble Worſhip may ſay your pleaſure. I know you love men that ply their Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I am for men of few words. Let ſuch a one anſwer to Maſaquedit. Here's the Founders health.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Tope.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Signior Sancho, you made a promiſe of Fiddles. I pray forbear your ſpoon while that you may call for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sancho
sp.p: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Servant I pray do.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Signior Sancho, let us have fair play. Did you invite your Beard to half the Poſſet?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Few words are beſt.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: In what ſence Signior Sancho?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: In Poſſet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Come, Sir, diſpatch; for brevity is as convenient in Poſſet as it is in Speech. I'll give you a Song if you will call for Muſick.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Firk your Fidles.

div.head: The SONG in Recitativo and in Parts.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: THe Bread is all bak'd,
The Embers are rak'd;
'Tis Midnight now by Chanticlears firſt crowing.
Let's kindly carouſe
Whilſt 'top of the Houſe
The Cats fall out in the heat of their wooing.
Time, whilſt the Hour-glaſs does run out,
This flowing Glaſs ſhall go about.
Stay, ſtay, the Nurſe is wak'd, the Child does cry,
No Song ſo antient is as Lulla-by.
The Cradle's rockt, the Child is huſht agen,
Then hey for the Maids, and ho for the Men.
Now ev'ry one advance his Glaſs;
Then all at once together claſh,
Experienc'd Lovers know
This claſhing does but ſhow,
That as in Muſick ſo in Love muſt be
Some diſcord to make up a harmony.
Sing; ſing! When Crickets ſing why ſhould not we?
The Crickets were merry before us;
They ſung us thanks e'r we made them a fire.
They taught us to ſing in a Chorus:
The Chimney is their Church, the Ov'n their Quier.
Once more the Cock cryes Cock-a-doodle-dooe.
The Owle cryes o'r the Barne, to-whit-to-whooe!
Benighted Travellers now loſe their way
Whom Will-of-the-wiſp bewitches:
About and about he leads them aſtray
Through Boggs, through Hedges and Ditches.
Heark! heark! the Cloyſter Bell is rung!
Alas! the Midnight Dirge is ſung.
Let 'em ring,
Let 'em ſing,
Whilſt we ſpend the Night in love and in laughter.
When Night is gone
O then too ſoon.
The diſcords, and cares of the Day come after.
Come Boyes! a health, a health, a double health
To thoſe who ſcape from care by ſhunning wealth.
Diſpatch it away
Before it be day.
'Twill quickly grow early when it is late:
A health to thee,
To him, to me,
To all who Beauty love and Bus'neſs hate.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Well, my Man were an incomparable Varlet if he would forbear to give me counſel in whiſpers. Todelet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Lead 'em a Dance. I'll have a Dance.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: My feet are at your ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whiſpers Todelet.
sp.p: As you ſhall feel to morrow by a ſcore of kicks which I reſerve for you.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Heark, he's giving me counſel agen. I ſay lead 'em a Dance.

div.stage: The DANCE. Which being ended a Bell rings within.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: My Ladies little Dog has wak'd her. Alas! now the ſweet of the Night is coming we muſt all part.

sp.speaker: D. John. whiſpers Tod.
sp.p: Sirrah, follow me to my Chamber.

div.stage: Exeunt all ſeveral wayes but Todelet.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.l: Not to night good Signior Don John.

I'll ſooner follow a D • um that beats for Volunteers to the North of Norway. The back dore of the Garden is only bolted within. I'll ſteal forth, and to morrow when ſleep has made him tamer I'll return.
I'll rather feed with Fiends on Brimſtone-Broth
Than eat Sack Poſſet with a man of wrath. Exit.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: YOu are very inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And you are very ſecret.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do you intend me that as commendation?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Yes, and yet I do not thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You may take your praiſe back agen, for I will not be commended for keeping that ſecret which I do not know.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Can you be ignorant of the Lady whom you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I told you I had not ſerv'd her above three dayes. But ſtill you are inquiſitive and why I pray?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: The endeavour of knowing things ſhews diligence of the Mind, and you ſhould praiſe me for it.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Thoſe may praiſe Spies who employ 'em.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: You take me then for a Spy?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: So impertinent a Spy that I wonder you do not walk with a dark Lanthorn when the Sun ſhines.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: What to ſeek chaſte women as Diogenes ſought honeſt men. Come, I confeſs you have wit.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I would you would thank me for being in love with your beauty.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Love! Is that Fooles-Bauble in faſhion ſtill?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: 'Tis the only faſhion which never changes.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Bettris will hardly believe you.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: No, ſhe believes in nothing but Marriage.

sp.speaker: Latra.
sp.p: O, cry you mercy, for indeed Marriage is grown as dangerous as love is fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I'll retire to make that Coxcomb j • alous. Exit Steph.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: How! hah!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: O Signior Sancho, 'tis well you are come.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Too well.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Your Friend Stephano would fain be your Rival, but you are the man for whom I mean to ſigh.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Yes, much!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I'll lay my life you are jealous.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Who, I?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pray come from behind your Beard and ſhew your bare face if you are angry.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: If you are, I can endure it.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You can?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.p: Who cares?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You do.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Not this — Makes a ſign of diſdain with his thumb at his teeth.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: 'Tis ill.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: 'Tis not.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: You ly.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Hey too!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Farewell.—

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Goe.— Exit Sancho,

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: How now Miſtreſs Laura?

sp.speaker: Laura,
sp.p: This Steward, though he be exceeding dull, is very ſharp at reparties.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Why, what has he ſaid?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: He gave me the ly.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If he did not I'm an E'vnuch.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: None but a E'vnuch would have don't.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand has been gallant in his youth: he ſhall repair my honour.
I'll tell him how often this Tarquin-Steward would have kiſt me by force.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Kiſs you! fy, that's a paw-word.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: No, no, he's a cleanly man, and would only have bruſht your lips with his Beard.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: May be ſo, for they grow ſomewhat duſty for want of uſe.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand ſhall not wake his ſleeping ſword in this quarrel; t • uſt me for your revenge.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Why, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I'll render Sancho up to your correction, and he ſhall be then as blind as Cupid.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: He ſhall feel our perſecution and not ſee it.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You have ſome deſigne, but 'tis very dark.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You know the Ladies and our Maſters are lately much retir'd with thoughtfull intanglements of love and anger: which will give me opportunity to invite ſolemn Sancho this Evening to our Room of Revels in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You likewiſe know, he paſſionately loves a Sack-Poſſet.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Moſt longingly.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Then you apprehend my Baite; but inſtead of that for his entertainment he ſhall entertain us with ſport ſufficiently ridiculous, though it be more out of faſhion than himſelf or a Morrice.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I long to ſee it but —

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: No more queſtions. Let's preſently go in and conſult.

sp.speaker: Iſabella.
sp.p: You muſt not think of your eſcape from hence.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.l: Whilſt you are civil you are cruell too.
Fair Iſabella, let me take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: My Father is not eaſily deceiv'd;
Whilſt you attempt it you deceive your ſelf.
Your reconcilement with your Brother may
Seem difficult at firſt, but if you doubt
My Fathers skill to govern him, you muſt
Depend on Heav'n, and then you muſt have faith;
Which out of Temples we call Courage.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.l: Nothing but death can quench my Brothers wrath,
Pray free your ſelf from the unfortunate;
Theſe Tears agree not with your Nuptial joys;
And let me tell you (what you ſoon will find)
Don John is nothing leſs than what he ſeems.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I ſaw him in the Garden but juſt now, and my Maid
Walking towards him. Go hide your ſelf.
Paſſe through the Gall'ry up the Tartas-ſtairs into my Cloſet, where
I will meet you ſtrait. I will awhile conceal my ſelf in ſome cloſe
Arbor to obſerve him and Bettris together. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Some heav'nly power contrives theſe accidents; they have a ſecret Method in them, and more than Fortune makes me ſtill unhappy.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I am amaz'd that you by chance ſhould court her whom you forſook, and meet the Miſtreſs here from whom you fled ſo many Miles.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Haſt thou diſcourſt with her Maid?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Yes, but ſhe is newly come into her ſervice, and is either a ſtranger to her Ladies deſignes, or elſe ſo ſecret that no man but a Husband can ſee her boſom bare.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Heav'n takes Lucilla's part againſt me, for I have done her wrong.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: O, have you ſo? you Lovers are very diligent Spies and bold, but very incredulous; you alwayes are ſcouting abroad, yet never ſee or believe miſchief till you feel it.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I think ſhe loves me and with true paſſion.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: But you love another, and that's a rare remedy for her diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I am perplext beyond the help of reaſon. I know there are Laws againſt irregular Love, but Nature never made 'em. I would thou wert valiant.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: So would not I. I'm content to have no holes in my skin rather than pay a Surgeon to ſow 'em up.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Well, however I would thou had'ſt courage.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Then I ſhould be an Aſs in ſpight of my underſtanding, and fight for Fame, the Fools Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Don John's man is ſaucily inſolent, and his condition is below the revenge of my ſword; but if thou hadſt courage to undertake him —

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Sir, I never queſtion'd my own courage, and I wiſh no man may, for I, and others too may be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I am going now where I ſhall meet D. Ferdinand, who will bring me an account of Don John.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Sir, I told you my infirmity when you firſt receiv'd me under your Roof. I'll ſerve you faithfully, but I muſt obey the King, who does injoyn peace amongſt his Subjects.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Well, though thou haſt no courage, yet I am ſatisfy'd with thy diligence. I ſtole hither chiefly to make thee increaſe thy acquaintance with Laura, Lucilla's Maid: and whatſoever ſhall ſucceed upon this engagement of my honour, be ſure to endeavour that ſhe may give good impreſſions of me to her Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: This, Sir, is a work of peace, and I dare go through with it; but as for matters of ſtrife if you would take my advice —

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: No more words. I'll take no counſel from men that are afraid.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Well, Sir, Fortune be your Friend. But I humbly conceive that men of diſcretion ſeldom depend upon her curteſie.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I will aſſure you, Sir, you have been ſought, and for my part, I was ſo concern'd in your abſence that I offer'd to employ the Town-Cryer.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: It had been to no purpoſe, for that publick voice cannot be heard. Alas, he's grown hoarſe with crying for loſt Maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Sir, you are ſometimes merry, but alwayes wiſe.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Alas! not I! yet it ſeems I am of ſome importance, ſince I have been ſo much ſought. But who were the ſearchers?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Your Father-in-law, and Don Lewis. Your Ma • too was ſo ſad, as if he had not only loſt his Maſter, but his wages.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I owe him nothing but a Cudgel for being ſo ſaucy as to miſs me without my order. May not a Maſter ſteal out to ſeek a Miſtreſs unleſs he ask leave of his Man?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: But where were you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I was invited by a Friend to a diſh of ſtew'd Tripes with Garlick. What Key is that?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: It belongs to your Camber. Don Ferdinand has appointed you another lodging near the Garden.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I had rather it had been near the Kitchin. I eſteem his Cook above his Gardener. The ſteam of Beef to me, who am not overcurious, is better than the odour of violets. But why am I remov'd?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: The old Gentleman is afraid of ſcandall. And, to ſay truth, it might do ſome harm to you (I mean to your modeſt reputation) if, before the Marriage Night, you ſhould be lodg'd too near his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Nay, let her look to that; I care not what People ſay, when I am innocent. But, dear Bettris, thou doſt not know how much I love thee.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: How ſhould I know it? you take me to be old; I'm none of thoſe who pretend to knowledge.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: I ever lov'd one of thy complexion; ever: and ſince I ſaw thee firſt I have been as hot as any Pepper.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Why truly Sir (though I bluſh when I ſay it) I ever lov'd all the Don Johns in the world; and when you firſt came hither my fooliſh heart — but I'll ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Nay we muſt be ſecret: for if the leaſt notice be taken of it, I ſhall ſtrait have fluſhings in my face; and bluſh like a roſe.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I'm ſure you make me hide mine. I pray ſtand farther off.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: Poor little Fool. Well, innocence is a ſtrange thing; it makes us ſtrange to one another, but a little of that which ancient People call wickedneſs will make us familiar. I prythee ſhew me the way down to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bett. ſighing.
sp.p: Hey down a down! in troth y'are an odd man. You make me ſigh e'n when I ſing. Here take the Key: I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Pretty Thief! I could find in my heart to weep when I think thou wilt be hang'd for ſtealing mens hearts. Dear ſlut — I am Maudlin-kind, would I had one of thy Hoods to cover my face; I ſhall be ſo aſham'd if I'm ſeen thus whineing for thee. But 'tis no matter; go, lead the way to my Chamber. I'll ſneak after thee.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You muſt follow me apace then; for I'm a very light Huswife. She runs away.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: The Bunting is flown. Now I could e'n weep indeed. I muſt for very ſhame over-take her. Iſabel ſtarts from the dore and ſurpriſes him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Stay, Don John! what, are you courſing my Maid?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: We are only at Childrens play. Are you ſo old that you have forgot it? 'Tis hide-and-ſeek, and when Maids run away, then the Boys make haſte to catch 'em.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Is't nothing elſe? But however, I did not think you had been ſo wanton.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: The tricks of youth are left when we grow old.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: But you'l beget an ill opinion of your Chaſtity; and give me cauſe to doubt your affection.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Our future Spouſe, you may go ſpin! Madam-Nature is a greater Lady than you, and I was alwayes her humble ſervant; and thoſe who ſpeak againſt it may ſtop their mouths with a Fig.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: It ſeems you are diſpleaſ'd. I'll leave you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Moſt wiſe Lady, and alſo moſt beautiful, you cannot do better.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'll take your opinion. Fare you well, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Humph! Are you ſo proud becauſe of your portion: this is only her want of breeding. Methinks I counterfeit a Don John rarely; for Husbands of quality muſt be ſometime diſcontented with their Wives, and often pleaſ'd with their Maids.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Don John, I am glad (after ſome affection and care in ſeeking you) that you are not loſt.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Moſt carefull Sir, I alſo am glad, and for the ſeekers ſake, becauſe the loſs would be his. I think that was ſpoken agen like a Don John. But what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Have you heard nothing of your Man Jodelet? nothing from any of his acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I uſe not to converſe with my Mans Companions.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But ſomething, Sir, will be propoſ'd to you, which in a ſeaſon before Marriage, may be, perhaps, a little unpleaſant.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: How? what is it?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You muſt abſolutely; but, Sir, excuſe me, for I ſpeak with ſome regret.—

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: What, muſt I, Sir? Pray ſpeak the worſt, and let it out for your own eaſe, if you are troubled with keeping it in.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You are invited to the Field; and it imports you much.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Is that all? A turn or Two in the Field is wholeſome after a full ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But, Sir, it is to fight.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: That may import me much indeed. I do not like the phraſe of being invited to the Field to be kill'd. Men are very ſimple when they go into a Grave to take the Air.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: It is the faſhion, Sir, and men of honour have allow'd it.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: The faſhion? But, Sir, if, without reſiſtance, I am contented to go peaceably into the Field, why ſhould any man who meets me there be angry? eſpecially when, perhaps, his being pleaſ'd would at that time better agree with my diſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I am ſorry for't: I held you to be an old Gentleman of a long underſtanding: but to ſpeak plainly, why ſhould a man take the pains to walk a mile to meet another who is of a different humour?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Have you been bred to ask that queſtion?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand, you ſeem ſometimes not very wiſe. I doubt that in your youth y'have been inclin'd to this fooliſh way of invitations to the Field, and have been hurt in the head. I ſay your reaſon at preſent is not exceeding ſound.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Come, Courage Don John; and firſt let me know, why you inferr I am not wiſe?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Becauſe you come to tell me of a quarrel which I knew not, nor perhaps did not deſire to know.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, in this I have done my duty, and you'l do well t'acquit your ſelf of yours, without being ſerv'd by the valour of another. To day you ought t'encounter him who kill'd your Brother. And I am ſorry, Sir, to tell you, that he kill'd him in the night.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Hay! was it at night?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I, Sir, at night.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Then for my part, let the Devil fight with his own match; for if he be able to kill a man without ſeeing him, he will be ſure to kill me when he ſees me.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: This ſounds ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Beſides, Sir, this dangerous Enemy fights by advantage, for having found the way how to kill one of my kindred, he knows by that, the faſhion how to kill me.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, you ought to conſider—

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, I have well conſider'd it, and muſt tell you, as a great ſecret, that all the family of the Alverads do ever fight one and the ſame way.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Don John! do you think that you have courage?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: A plague on it; I have but too much. Alas, 'tis not for that, Sir, do not ask me whether I have courage, but rather tell me where he lives? Is't far from hence? Muſt I ſtay for him? or do you know his Lodging? Or may I inquire it out? and, in the mean time, tell me but his name.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: It is Don Lewis de Rochas.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: A pox on him. I knew he would ſcape my hand. Don Lewis de Rochas? why that's your Nephew. Sir, you muſt know I reverence all men of your name.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I partly thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Any man of the Family of the Rochas is ſo conſiderable to me that I will lay my head at his feet. And particularly, as for Don Lewis, if you pleaſe, I am very well pleaſ'd to love him.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But, Sir, I have not told you all; for he has done a ſecond injury, which ſhould more provoke you to revenge. Your Siſter has too much reaſon to complain of him.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, as for my Siſter, truly he may be aſham'd to wrong her; but I have made a vow, and the Ladies muſt pardon me for it—

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What was your vow?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Never to draw my ſword in a Womans quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sir, I am much deceiv'd if you are not a Coward.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Ah Father-in-law! if that could poſſibly be, yet your diſcretion ſhould not meddle in nice things, which (by the care I ought to take) ſhould never concern you.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But you ſhall know that it concerns me much.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Bleſſe me! what a ſtrange Father-in-law would you be? Has the Devil ſent you hither to tempt me? not only to homicide, but alſo to kill my new allyance, your Nephew; nay and before conſummation, which, for ought I know, may likewiſe kill your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I would thou wert valiant but one minute, that, without loſs of my honour, I might kill thee befo • e thou grow'ſt a Coward agen.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: O fie, Don Ferdinand, I have found your diſpoſition; you would fain be too cruel; but I'm reſolv'd to be mercifull; and will not tell you how valiant I am.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: But I am now reſolv'd to tell you, that your man has given his word to fight for you.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: His word? The jealous Coxcomb needs not keep it; for I did never doubt his courage.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, if he will needs fight for me, let him know I ſhall not be jealous that my own valour is leſs than his.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: And yet you will not fight, either for your Brother or your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: A man muſt be in humour when he fights, and let me dy like a Dog (which I would not ſay falſely to get the whole world) if, to my remembrance, I ever had a leſs diſpoſition to fighting than now. Miſtake me not, I ſpeak but according to my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well, I thought you valiant, but I am couſen'd.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, I confeſs I have taken too much pleaſure in deceiving the world, for I have couzen'd many who thought me valiant, and many who thought me a Coward.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You have given your ſelf a rare recreation.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: But, Sir, let's leave the pleaſant part of our diſcourſe, and be a little ſerious.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Do ſo, but with as much brevity as you can.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I pray tell me, Sir, Suppoſe that with a Sahagun, or with a Rapier of Toledo, I were pierc'd like a Cullender, or ſuppoſe that with a Syrian Scemiter, or a Backſword-blade of Houndſlough, I were minc'd into a Py; how would my Brother, or my Siſter be the better for it?
Well, for your Fathers ſake my antient Friend, I'll leave you whole, without being either pierc'd or minc'd.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: For his ſake, Sir, I will with patience endure your curteſie.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You ſhall do well in doing ſo; but for my own ſake, you muſt, inſtead of my Daughter, ſeek another Wife in Madrid.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: What, you would have a Cid to your Son-in-law, that ſhould kill you firſt, then marry Chimena?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Expect nothing from me but ſcorn and hatred. O incomparable Coward!

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I am (O Don Ferdinand!) deſpite of your cruelty, and of your black Teeth, your moſt humble and moſt faithful Servant; and I am as much, or more, to the Lady Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
I am not yours; and when you are out of my houſe (which
muſt be ſodainly, and without noiſe) I ſhall do my ſelf the diſhonor to force you to another kind of account.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand! I pray, Sir, what puts you into choller?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: My ill choice of a curſed Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand, I'll be gon, that you may ſpeak better of a Friend behind his back. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Let him go Jodelet. He diſavows you in all, and has told me plainly, he was not of opinion that he ought to take notice of injuries; and that he was never inclin'd to revenge. Nay he has almoſt profeſt that he has loſt his courage.

sp.speaker: D. John aſide.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange that he took no more care to keep it having ſo little.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Pray call him back to ſave his honour. Tell him what he ought to do, being doubly affronted by Don Lewis. Dear Jodelet, ſhew the friendſhip of a Servant by perſwading a Maſter to courage.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſure he has a kind of Country-courage.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I mean, he's very obſtinate, and will ſeldome yield to perſwaſion.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for his Fathers ſake; eſpecially ſince I have proceeded ſo farr towards an allyance. If I were doubly injur'd as he is, I ſhould not behave my ſelf like him. His enemy ſtays for me at the end of the Street: I'll go to him.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Do, Sir, for my Maſter is come back, though I fear I ſhall find him too haughty to be councell'd into courage.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Is he gone, Sir?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Yes, but tell me Jodelet, what new affront have we to revenge?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p:
I am the Son of a Sow if he has not remov'd my patience ſo farr from me that I can hardly reach it agen: yet I'm as unwilling to be angry as another. Sir you muſt diſguiſe your ſelf no longer.
Theſe falſe habits may grow to be Fools Coats, and Don Lewis will turn all into laughter. But you did challenge him for me?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Yes, and without telling him that I was Don John. And in troth I did ſuſpect that the young Gallant had courted Iſabella. In ſhort I found him hidden in her Chamber; and (but for an accident which I muſt conceal from thee) we ſhould have met in the Field.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: That is to ſay, you had invited him to take the Air in a Grave.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I have deferr'd the buſ neſs till I ſee one thing more evident, which is yet but the ſubject of my ſuſpicion: for, perhaps, I may find it but a falſe-Game which Bettris plays to get mony.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: That Baggage carries her Purſe in her Boſom; and according to the Northern Proverb) is as liquoriſh at a Penny as at a Poſſet.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I have ſome reaſons to believe that Iſabella is very ignorant of the Artefice.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, there may be more in't than you ſuſpect. I'm loth to ſay it, but (if I could ſpeak without making any words) I would tell you that I think Don Lewis offends you in private.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Ah, ſay no more: I gueſs too much. All my paſt miſfortunes and the preſent concurre againſt me: but I have ſome comfort yet, for no body takes notice of it.

sp.speaker: Tod.
sp.p: None know it (for ought I know) unleſs it be the People.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Thou mak'ſt me mad. I will conſider nothing but revenge.
Is Don Ferdinand our Friend or Enemy?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Don Lewis is of his blood; but for the honour of yours, he does th • t which no man ever did for another. He would have Don Lewis give you ſati • faction, and Don Lewis ſtays for me near this houſe • who ſtill believes me to be Don John.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I muſt kill him: but men of action are often parted in the ſtreet. The warr which Honour makes in ſtreets does quickly end in peace, and I grow doubtful where to fight.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: 'Tis great pity there is not ſome Amphitheatre; built at the publick charge of Butchers, for the honorable exerciſe of cutting mens throats.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Revenge is often interrupted in the Field, becauſe now
even all peculiar Fields are turn'd to common Roads about this populous Town. If I could find ſome Houſe, though 'tis againſt the faſhion uſ'd in Duels —

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Stay, Sir. I'll fit you with a place. I have the Key of a low Apartment where we are to lodge. There you may conveniently be reveng'd, almoſt in the ſight of your Miſtreſs, and yet neither ſhe nor her Father can ſee it.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Thou haſt made an excellent choice my dear Jodelet.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: My dear Don John.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Go and appoint him a meeting in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: But rather, Sir, do you go. 'Tis now high time that men ſhould know who you are. How can you think to continue your fury and paſs for Jodelet? Go, go, Sir, diſcover your ſelf, and fight ſoundly. Revenge is a hearty food for thoſe who have a ſtomach to't.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: How Jodelet? becauſe for a meer provocation of jealouſie, for a ſimple ſuſpicion, I have diſguiſ'd my Name, wilt thou therefore have me diſcover my ſelf before the injury be evident? No, thou ſhalt remain Don John a while, and invite him to the low Chamber, to meaſure Weapons there, and to conſult about contriving the privacy of the Duell.

sp.speaker: Jod
sp.p: Then you command me to be ſtill Don John?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I do rather conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Well I obey you, Sir. But if by chance (as men are often impatient) he ſhould draw his ſword before he enters this Houſe, what ſhall Jodelet do? who has no inclination to warr, and is, perhaps, contented to ſojourn in this fooliſh world.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Make ſignes to him farr off. He's prompt, and will not fail to follow thee till he comes where I will ſtay to kill him.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: There's another ſcruple, which lies in the very bottom of my Bowels.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: He may be ſhort ſighted, and thinking my ſword drawn, may run at me.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Fy, fy! thy imagination is too ſubtil. He has an Eye like an Eagle and will diſtinguiſh, at a miles diſtance, any little Fly from a Flea. Thou ſhalt becken him far off, then lead him to me.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p:
Theſe appointments are ſomewhat hard. But, Sir, pray be
ſure that you likewiſe take heed of miſtakes. Mens eyes are often dazled with choller. If I (without thinking of you) ſhould enter before Don Lewis; and you (without thinking of me) ſhould run a tilt at my Belly—

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Thou haſt a Jeſuitical way of making impoſſible ſcruples.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, I know if I am wounded, you
Will cry, in troth, poor Jodelet, I'm ſorry;
Excuſe a fooliſh chance! Then I, good ſoul,
Shall quickly be contented and ſoon whole.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Enter Iſabella, Lucilla, Bettris. A Candle on the Table.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: MAdam Bettris, what do you here?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I am preparing a warm Chamber for your benum'd Lover; and, I beſeech you, from whence come you, and Madam Lucilla.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: We have been ſighing in a ſhade.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: Madam, I muſt tell you agen, if fortune ſhould bring the whole Sex of Men before you, and give you leave to make your own election, you could not chuſe a more worthy Husband than Don John; and when you know him better, you will confeſs my belief is guided by reaſon.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And I muſt needs declare (ſince your opinion is ſo confident againſt mine) that one of us is very ignorant.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: You make me wonder, Madam; but if all wonder did not proceed from ignorance, I ſhould not quickly yield in this debate.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Alas you are his Siſter; and that may well excuſe your partiality, you may allow me liberty to tell you this becauſe we have contracted a friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Were I my Miſtreſs, if there were no more men in the world, I would marry Don John, becauſe I would have children, and becauſe all children are not like the Father.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.p: Bettris, I cannot be angry when you pleaſe to be merry.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, what ever your griefs be, I wonder you are not merry too, for Don John makes all the world laugh.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Bettris, you are too rude.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, you are too grave. If I were to be Bride; like you, I would not carry my ſelf like a Nun.

sp.speaker: Iſabel aſide.
sp.p: I am unhappy above the help of Fortune; ordain'd to be poſſeſt of what I hate, and by unnatural cuſtome I am made aſham'd of what I love.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Madam, let us haſten up ſtairs, ſome Noiſe within like a Key turning a Lock. aſide. body opens the Dore and will ſurpriſe us. 'Tis Laura, who (as I appointed) makes a noiſe about the Lock to fright theſe Love-ſick Ladies and make them retire to take their Med'cine of ſighs. Madam, I hear't agen.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: You are ſcar'd.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: If you had been as often privately in love as I have been, youl'd ſoon be afraid at the opening of a Dore.
So, let them feed on ſorrows of Love; which is commonly at Court the ill ſecond Courſe at the promiſing Feaſts of Lovers, whilſt we, poor Wenches, are contented with Country ſports. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sancho, Stephano, and Laura, with a Scarfe in her hand, another Spaniard and two young Women.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: The ly, Signior Sancho, is hard of digeſtion; but, having firſt ſwallow'd the gilded Pill of Love, it prepares the ſtomach for any thing.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: And I have ſaid ſo much, to cure your jealouſie, as would make an old Italian truſt his Wife with a young Painter, and leave her with him to draw her naked.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Not naked.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: You ſhall, beſides the materials of our laſt Collation, have an innundation of Olio, where you may bathe your knuckles till you cure 'em of the Gout.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But we muſt inable our appetites with exerciſe. We have appointed a Dance for Blind-man-Buff, in which you ſhall be hoodwinkt, and appear all over, Cupid the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Bating Beard.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Come, Gentle Love, let me blind you; and then—

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Collation.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: 'Tis prepar'd within.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Mighty Olio's?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: A Sea of Olio, and in it Hams of Baijon lying at Hull with Sailes furl'd up of Cabbidge-leaves.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Then Bisks.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Imbroyder'd with Piſtachoes.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And Muſſels?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Broyl'd; and then (to make you corpulent) roaſted Cheſtnuts ſtew'd in Gravy.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And Chitterings.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: I, I, to fill up Chinks.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: And Ragous?

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Strew'd over with Salt-peter and Jamaica-Pepper, to make you thirſt for whole Flagons of Scargos and Ravidavio; and you ſhall be a very —

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Drunken Cupid.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pray Love be humble and ſtoop a little —

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I yield. Laura hoodwinks Sancho with a Scarf.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: We have now both place and opportunity for mirth. The Ladies are retir'd, Don Ferdinand's abroad, the three Strangers are ſeverally diſperſt, and gone, I think, in the queſt of wandring Love.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: We have a ſtayd old Cupid here who wears his Quiver in his Pocket, full of Tooth-picks inſtead of Arrows, in expectation of a Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What, blinded already? Come then, let's begin.

div.stage: They put themſelves into ſeveral Stations and Sancho in the middle.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: Now we have blinded ſo your ſight
That ev'n at Noon the Rayes of light
Are loſt as if your Eyes were out,
Wee'll turn you once and twice about.
About, about; about agen;
Twice for the Maids, once for the men.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Here ſtands a Maid, and there a Man.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We all are near; catch whom you can.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.l: We cloſ'd your eyes leſt you ſhould ſee;
And ſo your Ears ſhall uſeleſs be.
For now, as in the calm of ſleep,
All ſhall commanded ſilence keep;
Leaſt any Man, or any Maid,
Be by diſtinguiſht voice betrayd.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Here ſtands a Maid and there a Man.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We'll all ſtart fair, Catch whom you can.

div.stage: They Dance, in which the men kick Sancho by turns, and he at ſeveral times ſayes the following words.
The Dance being ended a Bell rings.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: My Lady rings. She wants me. Let's away.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Where's Collation? He pulls down his ſcarfe.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Signior Sancho, I took the ly from you, and now you muſt accept of one from me. I promiſt you a Collation, but there is none. You muſt e'n faſt and pray for better manners.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: We did this to ſave you a labour: for when no Crums can fall upon your Beard you need not bruſh it.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I could eat—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: Thee. Exeunt Sancho one way, and the reſt at the other Dore.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I hear 'em coming. I'll leave the Dore open, take away the Key, and conceal my ſelf in the Alcove.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p:
Now where's the evil Spirit my Maſter? Hah! vaniſht! he's gone, quite gone! This Don Lewis is as famous as Cain for
matters of killing, and, which is worſe to me then no help, he ſhuts the Dore. Well, ſince I'm pent in I would I were but as valiant as an impriſon'd Cat, that I might fly at his face. 'Tis very inconvenient to be a Man without Manhood, O that Traitor, my Maſter!

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Now, Sir, we are incloſ'd, and may fight without interruption.

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: I would he were hang'd that is not here to part us.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: You mutter, Sir, you may expreſs your anger with your Sword.

sp.speaker: Jod,
sp.p: Who I, Sir? I ſcorn to mutter any thing againſt any man who will give me any reaſonable ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I was bravely invited and am ready to do you reaſon.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall alwayes report you are not only a very reaſonable man, but are alſo willing to conſider —

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: What mean you by conſider?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: That's well askt, Sir and I am apt to anſwer your queſtions, if you will ſpend a little time in diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Is this a time to be ſpent in words?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I ſee you are haſty; but, perhaps, I may have patience to hear you out.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: To hear me out? Do you take me for a Talker when I come to be in action?

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: This 'tis to meet with brute Beaſts that are not capable of diſcourſe. I'm quite forſaken. My Maſter has, certainly, no kind of conſcience—

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: What the Devil do you ſeek?

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: Two things, which I fear I ſhall not find, my valour and my Maſter.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: This is a myſtery! ſtill you are muttering, but what look you for?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I hope you are alone.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: How, Sir, do you bring me hither to ask that?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Lord you are ſo collerick that one cannot ſpeak to you: may not a man ask a queſtion for your good?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I have attended to ſee your ſword out; and Honour taught me that patience: but now I'll truſt you with no more time — He draws.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a long ſpit he draws? I have been a raw fellow at fighting, and now am like to be roaſted.
Come, Sir. Are you ready? for I ſcorn to take advantage.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: In t • oth I ſee you are a man of honour, and I could find in my heart to conſider a while how I may requite your curteſie.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Curteſie? I diſdain to receive it from you. Prepare your ſelf —

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay a lit • le, Sir!
Let me adviſe you as a Friend to lay aſide your paſſion when you fight, for in good faith you are too haſty.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Is this behaviour equal to your former heat? Methinks y • u grow cold. Your courage is an Ague, for it comes in fits. But I ſhall cure it.

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: Heav'n I thank thee heartily! for I ſpy my Maſter. Ah, Sir! come out! do you want courage?

div.stage: Speaks ſoftly to Don John behind him.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Retire as thou art fighting that thou mayſt amuſe him.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Quick, Sir, draw; for I have told you that I ſcorn to take advantage.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Nay an'you grow ſo angry, Sir, then I ſay agen, ſtay! for I ſcorn all advantages as much as you do. He takes up the Candle.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: If you have any odds I cannot ſee't.

sp.speaker: Jod
sp.p: Lord! how your paſſion blinds you? do you think I'm ſo baſe as to fight with Rapier and Candle againſt ſingle Rapier?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Lay down the light then.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Honour is a Fool in the Field when it wants ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I think he is madd; for ſtill he mutters and looks back. D. John, I ſuſpect the temper of your brain, as much as I doubt the c urage of your heart; you ſeem to have a great quantity of the Coward, but more of the Fool.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Not ſo much of the Fool as you ſuppoſe, Sir —

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: What art thou all Coward, and coverſt thy ſelf in darkneſs?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Did not you kill my Brother in the dark?

sp.speaker: D Lewis.
sp.p: If that will more incenſe thee, know, I did.

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: Then try your Cats eyes once ag • n. He retires.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: The Devil's in the Dice if you throw twice in and in, without any light.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Where are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jod.. aſide.
sp.p: What a fool were I if I ſhould tell him?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: You are baſhful, and would not have your courage ſeen.

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: I'm a little valiant when I ſpy no naked Weapon. Now good ſpeed to one puſh at hazard — He ſteps aſide, thruſts at great diſtance at firſt, & at laſt hits D. Lewis, then retires to the Alcove. I think that toucht ſomething. I hope I have not run my ſword through one of the Caeſars eyes in the Hanging —

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: The Wretch has drawn my bloud. I feel it, for it wets my hand. But now by this, more than before, he does deſerve to be my Enemy.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. within.
sp.p: I'm certain that's my Nephews voice. If I can feel no Key in the Lock, then mine will give me ent • ance.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Go forth from the Alcove or I'll ſtrangle thee.

div.stage: D. Ferdinand opens the Dore, and enters with a Light.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Hah! what's the buſineſs here my Friends?

div.stage: Jodelet ſteps out of the Alcove.
D. Ferd. lays hold on D. Lewis.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I'm taking ſatisfaction for my injuries.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I have loſt blood, and will be ſtrait reveng'd.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd,
sp.p: I'st by Stoccado, or Stramaſon?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: A thouſand Sathans take all good luck. I ſhall pay ſoundly for having the honour to give the firſt wound.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Let me ſee, Nephew? your hand is hu • t.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: 'Tis but a ſlight prick.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Would I had two in my right hand that I might get an excuſe to let my ſword fall.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Now my dear friends, fight freely! I come not here to make peace. The one (who ſuffers by a deep and double injury) is by promiſe to be my Son-in-law. The other is my Nephew, who muſt be ſatisfy'd for loſs of blood. I'll look on each with the ſame eyes which in my youth did love to ſee the exerciſe of honour. Fight, and fight bravely; but firſt let me place the light conveniently for both.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Your counſel wlll be quickly follow'd, Sir, by men who know your courage.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Rare counſel indeed, which exhorts us to a Duel. This old man is heartily wicked, and may be held the very Father of the Hectors.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: My anger makes me inſolent and cruel. And that I now may dare you to do more than you durſt do till darkneſs hid your fear, know, I've deceiv'd your Siſter, and have kill'd your Brother.

div.stage: D. John enters from the Alcove.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Since I am thus confirm'd, Honour has leave of conſcience to be bloody in revenge — Stay Sir!

sp.speaker: Jod. aſide.
sp.p: O, are you come? In true Tragedies let every man act his own part.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: You do not know Don John, Behold him here. You did deceive my S • ſter, and have kill'd my Brother; and are now, againſt your ſelf, th'audacious witneſs of ſuch double wickedneſs as Juſtice cannot hear but with a double ſence of anger and of ſhame. I wiſh you had more than a ſingle life to anſwer both.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: But is the Man become the Maſter?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Make haſte to let me know, which of the two is more worthy than the other to be my Enemy: which is Don John?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: That name is mine.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Then what is he?

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: I'm no Don John, I dare aſſure you, Sir; but yet am ſo well bred, that I can give way to my Betters in all quarrels.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Under a Servants name I have indur'd my injuries whilſt I had got no more than a ſuſpicion of th'offenders perſon to authoriſe my revenge; but ſince you proudly have declar'd you did thoſe injuries, you cannot think that I ſhould longer bear them. My thers blood incites me to revenge.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: The cry of blood may ceaſe when the revenge of it is near.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Know my revenge is heighten'd by that black diſhonour which has ſtain'd my Siſters beauty, to whom you have ignobly ſhewn a want of ſuch compaſſion as does uſe t'accompany true courage.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Are you the true Don John, renown'd for valour, and yet ſtrive, with ſoftning pity, to allay that courage againſt which your honour does conteſt?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: You ought to think my vengeance for my Brothers death allows not words to reſpite deeds: but, by degrees, I am proceeding to the reaſon of this ſhort delay.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: This is ſuch temper as I never knew.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: That I may make my Siſter feel my juſtice more than cruelty, let me be now oblig'd ev'n by an Enemy, with ſo much truth as men of noble Race can never want.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: What would you ask?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Whether your many vows (broken as faſt as ſworn) did not ſeduce my Siſter from her Father's houſe to ſeek you in diſguiſe? and whether in thoſe vows you did not make a ſacred Contract of immediate Marriage?

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: This Son-in law is as prudent as he is valiant; though I did pronounce the other Son-in-law a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: That's I. But patience, for I've already ſhed blood enough.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Though when our ſwords are drawn 'tis then no ſeaſon for confeſſion, yet, in a juſt compaſſion, for her ſake, I will declare a bluſhing truth. Your Siſter owes her affliction to my repeated vowes of Marriage.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I ſwear — by the honour of all Muſtachios, and of all the Beards in Spain, my Nephew is a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a horrid Oath was that? no choler ſhall tranſport me to ſwear by more Beards than my own.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Hadſt thou a heart ſo cruel as to o'rcome a Virgin by thy vowes, and then forſake her for her faith? Son-in-law I'm wholly now of your ſide, and will renounce my bloud in him; who does deſerve to have it ſhed not by a ſingle hand of Honour, but by confederacy of common force.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Now for the French mode of fighting! D. Ferdinand goes to D. John's ſide. I fear I ſhall, by a trick of honour, be made a Second to the wrong ſide.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Stay, Uncle! ſhall the virtue of Confeſſion make you my Enemy!

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Yes, where Divines are not the Duelliſts —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Hold, Don Ferdinand. My honour will not ſuffer me to ſhare in ſuch advantages.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: That's ſpoken like a true Don John.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Then I alone will fight with him. —

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: My honour will leſs yield that you, Sir, ſhould deprive me of my Enemy, Sir, I beſeech you, hold!

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Then take him to your ſelf; though ſuch who Traitors are to Virgins deſerve their puniſhment from every hand.

sp.speaker: D. John to D. Lewis.
sp.p: I have another queſtion now, to which a civil Foe will give reply; and 'tis to cure my greateſt pain, my jealouſie; ſo great a torment as I could not wiſh to my moſt fatal Enemy, no, not to you.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Sir, now you teach me to be civil. Proceed to tell me your diſeaſe if you will haſten to the remedy.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Know, I am jealous.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Of whom.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Of you.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Of me.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I ſaw you leap from the Balconee of this Houſe.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Did you ſee it?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw it, and, ſince that, found you conceal'd in Iſabella's Chamber.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. aſide.
sp.p: Hah! Can I have patience to hear more?

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: If I in this ſhall new confeſſion add to what I ſpoke before, you cannot think 'tis from th'effect of fear, for honour does oblige me to't. If I have been your Rival than my l • ve did wrong your Siſter rather than injure you becauſe I did not know Don John: and Honour now does joyn with Truth to make me call on Heav'n to aſſiſt me wh • n I Iſabella vindicate; who with diſdain refuſed all love but what her Father ſhould prefer.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. aſide.
sp.p: That is ſome motive for my patience.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: I further muſt declare that Bettris, to promote th'addreſs I made for Marriage, did, unknown to her Lady, hide me then in the Balc • nee, and after that conceal'd me in her Ladies Chamber; for which ſhe was in hazard of her ſervice.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd. aſide.
sp.p: I remember my Daughter would have diſmiſt her Service; which gives my patience another comfort.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: All my diſeaſe of jealouſie ends here, and I'll continue ſtill to be a civill Enemy, for I will thank you for my cure.
But now —

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay Don John! The next Demand belongs to me. Why did you make your viſit here in a diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Sir, it is fit you ſhould be ſatisfy'd. I chang'd my habit when I ſaw him ſcape from the Balconee, ſuppoſing in another ſhape, my jealouſie might ſooner be inform'd.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I hear enough. My honour now makes me forſake your cauſe, and leads me to the other ſide. You are my Enemy.

div.stage: He goes to the ſide of D. Lewis.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: 'Tis my misfortune then and not my choice.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: You came into my Houſe not as a Lover but a Spy; and with a ſtratagem (courſe, and below my dignity) advanc'd your man to wooe my Daughter. Prepare your ſelf for my revenge —

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Pray hold, Sir! hold! you puniſh me too much in taking from my Sword that Enemy who firſt made me his choice.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand, you never can ſo much provoke me as to raiſe my anger 'gainſt the Father of the Miſtreſs whom I love.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: You lov'd with too much inſolence, and doubtfully, when you deſign'd your Man to court her in your ſhape.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I may, without diſhonor, crave for that your pardon: and when you ſhall reſent my change of ſhape, you then forget Love's antient Hiſtories; for my diſguiſe is not the firſt that love has worn. But I conjure you by my Fathers friendſhip, to forgive the fooliſh Arts of Jealouſie.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Well, for his ſake, I am appeaſ'd, and bury your offence; but 'tis on this condition that I may now reſtrain your Combat till I treat with each for both.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: To this I yield.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: To ſhew that you have taught me temper I conſent by your example.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: My Maſter taught Don Lewis diſcretion and I taught it him. 'Twas ever ſaid of Don Jodelet, that he did much incline to peace.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: You, by your ſword, Don John, have leiſure to receive
Such ſatisfaction as your honour does require
For all my Nephews broken faith, which now
Afflicts your Siſter, but he can never bring her back to her fair Fame
Unleſs he marry her; and I preſume I need not now perſwade
What Juſtice and Religion does enjoyne.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis to D. John
sp.p:
I doubly am prepar'd. Firſt, I will meet your Siſter in the Temple to perform my former vows; and then
I will return and meet you here, or in the Field, to pay the debt I owe you for your Brothers bloud.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: D. John, none yet did ever celebrate the ſacred Rites of Hymen with a Tragedy; and I'm oblig'd to tell you that my Nephew often has lamented your unhappy Brothers death, who in the dark was wounded by miſtake, and I have heard my Nephew vow that he did wear your Brother in his boſome as his deareſt Friend.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: This truth which you affirm does more, perhaps, become your Tongue than mine whilſt I continue in this poſture 'gainſt an Enemy.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: The ſeaſon now is fit to tell, why I have here
Made ſome delay of my revenge. My Brother is alive.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Alive? Heaven is propitious in this wonder!

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: I am alike ſurpriſ'd with wonder and with joy!

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Much bloud my Brother loſt by that unlucky wound you gave him, which ſome hours depriv'd him of the chiefeſt ſignes of life; but, being to a Surgeons houſe remov'd, he was by his great Art, in a few dayes, made hopeful of his Cure. I did conceal the good ſucceſs even from my ſervants, and in Madrid divulg'd that he was dead.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: What could you mean by making that report?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I thought, Don Lewis, that the rumour of his death would make it harder for you to eſcape the rig'rous Law in order to my Siſters injuries, who then forſook my Fathers Houſe in your purſuit.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: My dear Don John, ſince you perceive your Brother only wounded by miſtake, and that wound cur'd: Don Lewis and your Siſter ready to be joyn'd by Hymens hand, and I prepar'd to make my Iſabella yours; let me behold a knot of Friendſhip ty'd between two Enemies. Come both, and chearfully embrace.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Don Lewis, all offences paſt ſhall vaniſh like the dreams of Infancy.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: And all that we hereafter to each D. John and D. Lewis embrace. other do, ſhall laſt like the examplar deeds of men renown'd.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Peace is proclaim'd. I'll reſt contented with honour gotten in the dark, and ſheath my Sword as Gameſters put up falſe Dice, to hide 'em after they have won money.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Come Iſabella, you ſhall now, and with your own conſent, be given to Don John.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: with my conſent? Are there ſuch Miracles when Lucilla ſaies all faith is loſt; or elſe at leaſt, that men have none.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Behold the true Don John.

sp.speaker: Iſab. to Ferd.
sp.l: Though I'm not worthy of your favour, Sir,
Yet uſe me not with ſcorn.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: You may perceive my joy, and cannot think it counterfeit.
You ſhall know more before I lead you to the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: This is a Miracle which I am willing to believe.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Give me your hand, which muſt be mine no more, for it is now your Nuptial Pledge.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Give me your pardon, Madam, 'ere I take your hand,
Pardon the cauſe for which I did aſſume
My Servants ſhape; but I am now the true Don John.

sp.speaker: Iſab. aſide.
sp.p: Prophetick Love! thou taught'ſt me to believe it e're he ſaid it.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Bettris, I will not chide you now. This day permits no anger.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: Indeed I ever thought this was the true Don John.
Though, in the dark, I twice miſtook another for him:
Which made me hide Don Lewis; firſt in the Balconee,
Then in my Ladies Chamber.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Go, go, make haſte; and call the Lady Lucilla.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Truly ſhe was miſtaken, Sir. Her eyes are much decay'd with watching late to prevent th'unlucky meeting of Lovers.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Come, Siſter, you ſhall weep no more. Enter Lucilla and Bettris. Don Lewis is your beſt Phyſitian and can cure your grief. He is my Preſent to you; take him, and forgive him.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Can you forgive me, Madam? The Prieſt will do it when he joyns our hands.

sp.speaker: Lucilla.
sp.l: He is ordain'd to be th'example ſtill of what
We are to do; and I ſhall quickly follow it.
This is a ſodain change; I will not now examine how it comes, nor chide you when you tell it me.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Bettris, you have a great mind to take my hand too.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Troth you muſt waſh it firſt: for when your Gloves were off I ſtill ſuſpected that you were no more than an uncertain Don, called Jodelet.

sp.speaker: D. Lewis.
sp.p: Don Jodelet, I have a ſmall mark of your favour, which I wear on my right hand: but I intend not to requite it till you are Don John agen.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.p: Sir, you may deferr your requital as long as you pleaſe, you know I'm one of thoſe who ſcorn to be too haſty in calling for ſatiſfaction when men are any thing willing to give it.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.l: The Clouds which hover'd o'r my Roof to day
Are all diſpell'd. Make me your guide. I'll lead
You firſt to Church, and then prepare for Feaſts.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Why ſhould we ſtay liſt'ning here any longer? We have heard 'em talk of ſtrange changes, and of wonders more fortunate than we could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Steph.
sp.p: Don Ferdinand ſpoke of Feaſts: we cannot have a better Cue for our entrance. We may ſafely ſtep in, Signior Sancho.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: We may.

sp.speaker: D. Ferd.
sp.p: Come happy Lovers, follow me.

sp.speaker: Jod.
sp.l: Pray ſtay a while. For matters may not paſſe
So ſmoothly as you think. Madam, you have
Of mine a little Picture which you pleaſe
To pin upon the Curtain of your Bed:
You keep the Picture, yet are well content
To loſe th'Original. That's fine i'faith
Sweet Lady, Humph! but 'twill not do. Reſtore
It to me or be ſure you never walk
Abroad alone after the Sun is ſet.
Don Jodelet is ſuch a furious Spark

l.hi: As will have ſatisfaction in the Dark.

div.head: The Epilogue. In a BALLAD, ſung by Two.

lg.l: Ladies, who fine as Fi'pence are,
You Men with bright Roſe-noble Hair,
Both all and ſome, for we now except none
O thruſt out your Ears and lift to our mean.
Attend and eke hearken out of pure pitty
To tydings dolefull, yea in a ſad ditty.
The Players grow poor and down they muſt fall,
Though ſome ſay they get the devil and all.
Alack, and alas! our hearts are e'n broken:
But becauſe in all Plays
You ſtill look for new wayes
We mean now to ſing what ought to be ſpoken.
Since now thoſe Poets get the Vogue
Who ſtill, with a bold Epilogue,
Dare rattle Spectators and cry 'em down,
As you do their Plays, we'll tell you your own.
Firſt, loving kind friends, who come from the Citty,
You never think any Play can be witty
But that in which Courtiers ſhrewdly are jeer'd.
Out on it, and fy! was e'r the like heard?
Why would you have us to bob and to gibe 'em,
When the wiſer complain
That in private, for gain,
You are the men who endeavor to bribe 'em.
Some Gallants, though nameleſs, come here
Expecting our Poets ſhould jeer
The City for Cuſtards and for the Show
When Pageants through rain do paſs to and fro.
Thoſe very old frumps, perhaps, would be pretty;
But, Gallants, we have not the dulneſs to fit ye.
They grow too ſtale, and the Reader who looks
Upon the ſad Notes of many Shop-books
Will think that the Cits have ſeldome undone ye.
Rather you, ev'ry year,
Spoil their Shows and their Chear,
For they want your Wit, and you have their Money.
Now up wi' Boots, and have at all!
Ev'n you whom we Town-Gallants call;
Who with your round Eeathers make a great ſhow;
We mean you did wear ſuch three years agoe;
Come then, and ſtand fair, that now we may hit ye,
Becauſe ev'n like Turks without any pity,
You viſit our Plays, and merit the Stocks
For paying Half-Crowns of Braſs to our Box.
Nay, often you ſwear, when places are ſhewn ye,
That your hearing is thick,
And ſo, by a Love-trick,
You paſs through our Scenes up to the Balcone.
And ſome (a duce take 'em!) pretend
They come but to ſpeak with a friend;
Then wickedly rob us of a whole Play
By ſtealing five times an Act in a day.
O little England! ſpeak, is it not pity,
That Gallants ev'n here, and in thy chief City,
Should under great Perukes have heads ſo ſmall,
As they muſt ſteal wit, or have none at all?
Others are bolder and never cry, ſhall I?
For they make our Guards quail,
And 'twixt Curtain and Rail,
Oft Combing their hair, they walk in Fop-Ally.
Gallants relent and eke repent,
For your ſo foul nay, bad intent
Of paying us Braſs inſtead of true Coyne;
And, for amends we only enjoyn,
That ev'ry Man, to declare conſcience in ye,
Shall whiſper a Friend, and borrow a Guinny;
Which in our Box you may careleſly throw,
And pay him who lends it to morrow to mow.
And now to conclude, 'tis fit to acquaint ye
That though this Epilogue
Does not flatter and cogg
Yet a new Ballad may paſs for a dainty.
